title: Bi-abundance ionization structure of the Wolf-Rayet planetary nebula PB 8
input: The planetary nebula (PN) PB 8 around a [WN/WC]-hybrid central star is one of PNe with moderate abundance discrepancy factors (ADFs ~ 2-3), which could be an indication of a tiny fraction of metal-rich inclusions embedded in the nebula (bi-abundance). In this work, we have constructed photoionization models to reproduce the optical and infrared observations of the PN PB 8 using a non-LTE stellar model atmosphere ionizing source. A chemically homogeneous model initially used cannot predict the optical recombination lines (ORLs). However, a bi-abundance model provides a better fit to most of the observed ORLs from N and O ions. The metal-rich inclusions in the bi-abundance model occupy 5.6 percent of the total volume of the nebula, and are roughly 1.7 times cooler and denser than the mean values of the surrounding nebula. The N/H and O/H abundance ratios in the metal-rich inclusions are ~ 1.0 and 1.7 dex larger than the diffuse warm nebula, respectively. To reproduce the Spitzer spectral energy distribution of PB 8, dust grains with a dust-to-gas ratio of 0.01 (by mass) were also included. It is found that the presence of metal-rich inclusions can explain the heavy element ORLs, while a dual-dust chemistry with different grain species and discrete grain sizes likely produces the infrared continuum of this PN. This study demonstrates that the bi-abundance hypothesis, which was examined in a few PNe with large abundance discrepancies (ADFs > 10), could also be applied to those typical PNe with moderate abundance discrepancies.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00892v2","explanation": "Planetary nebulas are complex systems formed by gas and dust expelled into space.

Key terms include planetary nebula (PN), abundance discrepancy factor (ADF), non-LTE stellar model atmosphere, and optical recombination lines (ORLs). A PN is a region of ionized gas surrounding a central star. An abundance discrepancy factor represents the ratio of observed to predicted elemental abundances in a PN.

In photoionization models, the interaction between the central star's radiation and the nebula's gas leads to the emission of ORLs. The presence of metal-rich inclusions affects this process by altering the observed elemental abundances within the nebula. These inclusions occupy about 5.6% of the total volume of the nebula.

A bi-abundance model provides a better fit to most ORLs from N and O ions, with metal-rich inclusions that are roughly 1.7 times cooler and denser than their surroundings. The N/H and O/H abundance ratios in these inclusions are significantly higher compared to the diffuse warm nebula."}

title: The GALEX Ultraviolet Virgo Cluster Survey (GUViCS). VII.: BCG UV upturn and the FUV-NUV color up to redshift 0.35
input: CONTEXT:At low redshift, early-type galaxies often exhibit a rising flux with decreasing wavelength in the 1000-2500 Å range, called "UV upturn". The origin of this phenomenon is debated, and its evolution with redshift is poorly constrained. The observed GALEX FUV-NUV color can be used to probe the UV upturn approximately to redshift 0.5. AIMS: We provide constraints on the existence of the UV upturn up to redshift 0.4 in the brightest cluster galaxies (BCG) located behind the Virgo cluster, using data from the GUViCS survey. METHODS:We estimate the GALEX far-UV (FUV) and near-UV (NUV) observed magnitudes for BCGs from the maxBCG catalog in the GUViCS fields. We increase the number of nonlocal galaxies identified as BCGs with GALEX photometry from a few tens of galaxies to 166 (64 when restricting this sample to relatively small error bars). We also estimate a central color within a 20 arcsec aperture. By using the -band luminosity from the maxBCG catalog, we can separate blue FUV-NUV due to recent star formation and candidate upturn cases. We use Lick indices to verify their similarity to redshift 0 upturn cases. RESULTS: We clearly detect a population of blue FUV-NUV BCGs in the redshift range 0.10-0.35, vastly improving the existing constraints at these epochs by increasing the number of galaxies studied, and by exploring a redshift range with no previous data (beyond 0.2), spanning one more Gyr in the past. These galaxies bring new constraints that can help distinguish between assumptions concerning the stellar populations causing the UV upturn phenomenon. The existence of a large number of UV upturns around redshift 0.25 favors the existence of a binary channel among the sources proposed in the literature.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.00985v1","explanation":"The universe's early-type galaxies reside in a region of low redshift where the interstellar medium is relatively calm, allowing for the observation of subtle changes in flux with decreasing wavelength between 1000-2500 Å.\n\nA UV upturn refers to an increase in flux as wavelength decreases within this range. This phenomenon can be probed using GALEX FUV-NUV color observations. The term "		}

title: Interpretation of increased energetic particle flux measurements by SEPT aboard the STEREO spacecraft and contamination
input: Context. Interplanetary (IP) shocks are known to be accelerators of energetic charged particles observed in-situ in the heliosphere. However, the acceleration of near-relativistic electrons by shocks in the interplanetary medium is often questioned. On 9 August 2011 a Corotating Interaction Region (CIR) passed STEREO B (STB) that resulted in a flux increase in the electron and ion channels of the Solar Electron and Proton Telescope (SEPT). Because electron measurements in the few keV to several 100 keV range rely on the so-called magnet foil technique, which is utilized by SEPT, ions can contribute to the electron channels. Aims. We aim to investigate whether the flux increase in the electron channels of SEPT during the CIR event on 9 August 2011 is caused by ion contamination only. Methods. We compute the SEPT response functions for protons and helium utilizing an updated GEANT4 model of SEPT. The CIR energetic particle ion spectra for protons and helium are assumed to follow a Band function in energy per nucleon with a constant helium to proton ratio. Results. Our analysis leads to a helium to proton ratio of 16.9% and a proton flux following a Band function with the parameters / (cm2 s sr MeV/nuc.), keV/nuc. and spectral indices of and which are in good agreement with measurements by the Suprathermal Ion Telescope (SIT) aboard STB. Conclusions. Since our results explain the SEPT measurements, we conclude that no significant amount of electrons were accelerated between keV and keV by the CIR.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01040v2","explanation": "The heliosphere is a vast region of space where the Sun's magnetic field and solar winds interact, creating conditions for interplanetary shocks to form.

A Corotating Interaction Region (CIR) can be thought of as a shock that accelerates charged particles. Key terms include Band function: a mathematical model describing energy spectra; GEANT4: a simulation tool used in particle physics; and magnet foil technique: an electron detection method sensitive to ions, which relies on the interaction between magnetic fields and charged particles.

When a CIR passes through the Solar Electron and Proton Telescope (SEPT), it causes a flux increase in both electron and ion channels due to the acceleration of charged particles. However, SEPT's ability to detect electrons is limited by its magnet foil technique, which can also register ions, potentially contaminating electron measurements.

The interaction between charged particles and CIRs involves complex processes where energetic particle ion spectra are assumed to follow a Band function in energy per nucleon with a constant helium to proton ratio. By analyzing SEPT's response functions for protons and helium, researchers found that the helium to proton ratio was 16.9% and the proton flux followed a specific Band function with parameters consistent with measurements by the Suprathermal Ion Telescope (SIT) aboard STB.

The analysis suggests that no significant amount of electrons were accelerated between keV and keV by the CIR, implying that ion contamination is responsible for the observed electron channel increase."}

title: The effect of metallicity on the atmospheres of exoplanets with fully coupled 3D hydrodynamics, equilibrium chemistry, and radiative transfer
input: In this work we have performed a series of simulations of the atmosphere of GJ~1214b assuming different metallicities using the Met Office Unified Model (UM). The UM is a general circulation model (GCM) that solves the deep, non-hydrostatic equations of motion and uses a flexible and accurate radiative transfer scheme, based on the two-stream and correlated- approximations, to calculate the heating rates. In this work we consistently couple a well-tested Gibbs energy minimisation scheme to solve for the chemical equilibrium abundances locally in each grid cell for a general set of elemental abundances, further improving the flexibility and accuracy of the model. As the metallicity of the atmosphere is increased we find significant changes in the dynamical and thermal structure, with subsequent implications for the simulated phase curve. The trends that we find are qualitatively consistent with previous works, though with quantitative differences. We investigate in detail the effect of increasing the metallicity by splitting the mechanism into constituents, involving the mean molecular weight, the heat capacity and the opacities. We find the opacity effect to be the dominant mechanism in altering the circulation and thermal structure. This result highlights the importance of accurately computing the opacities and radiative transfer in 3D GCMs.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01045v1","explanation": "The study of GJ~1214b's atmosphere is a complex task that involves understanding the interactions between gas and dust in this exoplanet's environment.

Metallicity refers to the proportion of elements heavier than hydrogen present in the atmosphere, while mean molecular weight is a measure of an ideal gas's average mass per molecule. The metallicity affects the heat capacity, or the amount of energy required to change the temperature of the gas by one degree. Opacities describe how effectively radiation can pass through the atmosphere.

In this context, opacities play a vital role in determining the heating rates and thermal structure of GJ~1214b's atmosphere. The study reveals significant changes occur in both dynamical and thermal structures as metallicity increases, impacting the simulated phase curve. By dissecting these effects, researchers found that opacity plays a dominant role in altering circulation patterns and temperature distributions.

The mechanism behind this phenomenon involves the interplay between mean molecular weight, heat capacity, and opacities. As metallicity increases, the atmosphere's thermal structure changes due to variations in heating rates caused by differences in radiative transfer. This process affects the simulated phase curve, leading to significant implications for understanding GJ~1214b's atmospheric behavior.

The study highlights that accurately computing opacities and radiative transfer is essential within three-dimensional general circulation models like the Met Office Unified Model (UM). The UM's ability to solve non-hydrostatic equations of motion makes it an ideal tool for investigating GJ~1214b's atmospheric dynamics."}

title: New Parallaxes of Galactic Cepheids from Spatially Scanning the Hubble Space Telescope: Implications for the Hubble Constant
input: We present new parallax measurements of 7 long-period (> 10 days) Milky Way Cepheids (SS CMa, XY Car, VY Car, VX Per, WZ Sgr, X Pup and S Vul) using astrometry from spatial scanning of WFC3 on HST. Observations were obtained at 6 month intervals over 4 years. The distances are 1.7--3.6 kpc with a mean precision of 45 microarcseconds and a best of 29 microarcseconds (SNR = 14). The accuracy of the parallaxes is demonstrated through independent analyses of >100 reference stars. This raises to 10 the number of long-period Cepheids with significant parallax measurements, 8 obtained from this program. We also present high-precision F555W, F814W, and F160W magnitudes of these Cepheids, allowing a direct, zeropoint-independent comparison to >1800 extragalactic Cepheids in the hosts of 19 SNeIa. This sample addresses two outstanding systematic uncertainties affecting prior comparisons of Milky Way and extragalactic Cepheids used to calibrate H_0: their dissimilarity of periods and photometric systems. Comparing the new parallaxes to their predicted values derived from reversing the distance ladder gives a ratio (or independent scale for H_0) of 1.037+/-0.036, consistent with no change and inconsistent at the 3.5 sigma level with a ratio of 0.91 needed to match the value predicted by Planck+LCDM. Using these data instead to augment the Riess et al. (2016) measurement of H_0 improves the precision to 2.3%, yielding 73.48+/-1.66 km/s/Mpc, and tension with Planck+LCDM increases to 3.7 sigma. The future combination of Gaia parallaxes and HST spatial scanning photometry of 50 Milky Way Cepheids can support a < 1% calibration of H_0.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01120v2","explanation":"The Milky Way's Cepheid population is situated within the galaxy, where stars undergo pulsations causing periodic changes in brightness and size.

A parallax measurement quantifies an object's distance from Earth by measuring how much its apparent position shifts against a background of more distant objects when viewed from opposite sides of our planet's orbit. In this context, astrometry refers to precise measurements of celestial positions and their changes over time. A microarcsecond is a unit of angular measurement used in astronomy.

The Cepheids' long periods are characterized by periodic pulsations that allow researchers to derive accurate parallax measurements using spatial scanning on the Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3). The observations were conducted at six-month intervals for four years, with distances ranging from approximately 1.7 to 3.6 kiloparsecs.

The new parallaxes are compared to their predicted values derived from reversing the distance ladder, yielding a ratio of 1.037+/-0.036 that is consistent with no change and inconsistent at the 3.5 sigma level with a ratio needed to match Planck+LCDM predictions."}

title: Diffusion and mixing in globular clusters
input: Collisional relaxation describes the stochastic process with which a self-gravitating system near equilibrium evolves in phase space due to the fluctuating gravitational field of the system. The characteristic timescale of this process is called the relaxation time. In this paper, we highlight the difference between two measures of the relaxation time in globular clusters: (i) the diffusion time with which the isolating integrals of motion (i.e. energy E and angular momentum magnitude L) of individual stars change stochastically and (ii) the asymptotic timescale required for a family of orbits to mix in the cluster. More specifically, the former corresponds to the instantaneous rate of change of a star's E or L, while the latter corresponds to the timescale for the stars to statistically forget their initial conditions. We show that the diffusion timescales of E and L vary systematically around the commonly used half-mass relaxation time in different regions of the cluster by a factor of ~10 and ~100, respectively, for more than 20% of the stars. We define the mixedness of an orbital family at any given time as the correlation coefficient between its E or L probability distribution functions and those of the whole cluster. Using Monte Carlo simulations, we find that mixedness converges asymptotically exponentially with a decay timescale that is ~10 times the half-mass relaxation time.

validation_errors: Likely copied from abstract (20+ word overlap detected).
output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01123v2","explanation":"A self-gravitating system of stars in a globular cluster is characterized by dynamic equilibrium, where each star's gravitational influence on its neighbors drives the evolution of phase space.

Key terms such as isolating integrals of motion and mixedness require clarification: Isolating integrals of motion refer to conserved quantities like energy (E) and angular momentum magnitude (L), which remain constant over long periods for individual stars. Mixedness, on the other hand, is a measure of how well an orbital family's probability distribution functions align with those of the entire cluster.

The relaxation process in globular clusters involves two distinct timescales: diffusion time and asymptotic mixing time. The former pertains to the instantaneous rate at which individual stars' E or L values change stochastically, while the latter represents the timescale for a family of orbits to statistically forget their initial conditions. This interplay between different regions within the cluster leads to varying levels of mixedness.

The diffusion timescales of E and L vary systematically around the commonly used half-mass relaxation time in different regions of the cluster by factors of ~10 and ~100, respectively, for more than 20% of the stars. Additionally, we find that mixedness converges asymptotically exponentially with a decay timescale roughly ten times that of the half-mass relaxation time."}

title: MUSE spectroscopy and deep observations of a unique compact JWST target, lensing cluster CLIO
input: We present the results of a VLT MUSE/FORS2 and Spitzer survey of a unique compact lensing cluster CLIO at z = 0.42, discovered through the GAMA survey using spectroscopic redshifts. Compact and massive clusters such as this are understudied, but provide a unique prospective on dark matter distributions and for finding background lensed high-z galaxies. The CLIO cluster was identified for follow up observations due to its almost unique combination of high mass and dark matter halo concentration, as well as having observed lensing arcs from ground based images. Using dual band optical and infra-red imaging from FORS2 and Spitzer, in combination with MUSE optical spectroscopy we identify 89 cluster members and find background sources out to z = 6.49. We describe the physical state of this cluster, finding a strong correlation between environment and galaxy spectral type. Under the assumption of a NFW profile, we measure the total mass of CLIO to be M M . We build and present an initial strong-lensing model for this cluster, and measure a relatively low intracluster light (ICL) fraction of 7.21 1.53% through galaxy profile fitting. Due to its strong potential for lensing background galaxies and its low ICL, the CLIO cluster will be a target for our 110 hour JWST 'Webb Medium-Deep Field' (WMDF) GTO program.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01140v1","explanation":"Galaxies reside within vast networks of dark matter, invisible yet influential forces governing the cosmos' large-scale structure. Dark matter is a type of matter that does not emit or reflect light and thus remains undetected directly. The CLIO cluster exists at a pivotal juncture in this web, boasting an exceptionally high mass and concentrated dark matter halo. \\n\\nThe NFW profile refers to a mathematical model describing the distribution of dark matter within galaxy clusters. It assumes that dark matter follows a specific density profile, enabling astronomers to estimate total masses. The intracluster light (ICL) fraction is a measure of the ICL's contribution to overall brightness. \\n\\nIn compact lensing clusters like CLIO, strong gravitational lensing effects occur due to massive objects bending light around them. This phenomenon allows researchers to study background galaxies at higher redshifts and gain insights into early universe evolution. The presence of observed lensing arcs in ground-based images underscores the cluster's potential for studying these effects. \\n\\nThe investigation reveals a significant correlation between environment and galaxy spectral type, suggesting that galaxies within CLIO are influenced by their surroundings. This is particularly evident under the assumption of an NFW profile, where researchers measure the total mass of CLIO to be M . The strong-lensing model yields a relatively low intracluster light (ICL) fraction of 7.21 ± 1.53%, implying minimal ICL contribution to overall brightness."}

title: Nucleon Effective Masses in Neutron-Rich Matter
input: Various kinds of isovector nucleon effective masses are used in the literature to characterize the momentum/energy dependence of the nucleon symmetry potential or self-energy due to the space/time non-locality of the underlying isovector strong interaction in neutron-rich nucleonic matter. The multifaceted studies on nucleon isovector effective masses are multi-disciplinary in nature. Besides structures, masses and low-lying excited states of nuclei as well as nuclear reactions, studies of the isospin dependence of short-range correlations in nuclei from scatterings of high-energy electrons and protons on heavy nuclei also help understand nucleon effective masses especially the so-called E-mass in neutron-rich matter. A thorough understanding of all kinds of nucleon effective masses has multiple impacts on many interesting issues in both nuclear physics and astrophysics. We review some of the significant progresses made in recent years by the nuclear physics community in resolving some of the hotly debated and longstanding issues regarding nucleon effective masses especially in dense neutron-rich matter.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01213v1","explanation":"Nuclear physics and astrophysics are deeply connected through the study of neutron-rich matter, a state characterized by an excess of neutrons over protons. This environment is crucial for understanding various phenomena in both fields.\n\nIsovector nucleon effective masses refer to the reduced mass experienced by nucleons due to their interactions with other particles in dense environments. These corrections arise from the strong interaction between nucleons and are essential for characterizing neutron-rich matter. The term "		}

title: The interaction of the halo around the butterfly planetary nebula NGC650-1 with the interstellar medium
input: With its bright and wide equatorial waist seen almost edge-on (the butterfly body) and the faint and broad bipolar extensions (the butterfly wings), NGC650-1 is the archetypical example of bipolar planetary nebula (PN) with butterfly morphology. We present here deep high-resolution broad- and narrow-band optical images that expose the rich and intricate fine structure of this bipolar PN, with small-scale bubble-like features and collimated outflows. A SHAPE spatio-kinematical model indicates that NGC650-1 has a broad central torus with an inclination angle of 75 degrees with respect to the line of sight, whereas that of the bipolar lobes, which are clearly seen in the position-velocity maps, is 85 degrees. Large field of view deep images show, for first time, an arc-like diffuse envelope in low- and high-excitation emission lines located up to 180 arcsec towards the East-Southeast of the central star, well outside the main nebula. This morphological component is confirmed by Spitzer MIPS and WISE infrared imaging, as well as by long-slit low- and high-dispersion optical spectroscopic observations. HST images of NGC650-1 obtained at two different epochs (14 yrs apart), reveal the proper motion of the central star along this direction. We propose that this motion of the star through the interstellar medium compresses the remnant material of a slow Asymptotic Giant Branch wind, producing this bow-shock-like feature.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01215v1","explanation":"The universe contains various types of planetary nebulas, but bipolar ones with butterfly morphology are particularly rare and intriguing objects.

A torus is a doughnut-shaped structure that can be found in the center of some galaxies or stars. Inclination angle describes how tilted an object is relative to our line of sight. Astronomers use arcseconds as a unit of angular measurement to describe distances between objects in the sky.

The interaction between the star's motion through the interstellar medium and the slow wind of an asymptotic giant branch compresses remnant material, generating a bow-shock-like feature that can be observed in NGC650-1. The proper motion of the central star along this direction suggests it plays a crucial role in shaping the nebula's morphology.

The presence of an arc-like diffuse envelope outside the main nebula is confirmed by infrared imaging and spectroscopic observations, indicating its relation to the interaction between the central star and its surroundings."}

title: Investigating the early evolution of planetary systems with ALMA and the Next Generation Very Large Array
input: We investigate the potential of the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and the Next Generation Very Large Array (ngVLA) to observe substructures in nearby young disks which are due to the gravitational interaction between disk material and planets close to the central star. We simulate the gas and dust dynamics in the disk using the LA-COMPASS hydrodynamical code. We generate synthetic images for the dust continuum emission at sub-millimeter to centimeter wavelengths and simulate ALMA and ngVLA observations. We explore the parameter space of some of the main disk and planet properties that would produce substructures that can be visible with ALMA and the ngVLA. We find that ngVLA observations with an angular resolution of 5 milliarcsec at 3 mm can reveal and characterize gaps and azimuthal asymmetries in disks hosting planets with masses down to au from a Solar-like star in the closest star forming regions, whereas ALMA can detect gaps down to planetary masses of at 5 au. Gaps opened by super-Earth planets with masses are detectable by the ngVLA in the case of disks with low viscosity ( ) and low pressure scale height ( au at 5 au). The ngVLA can measure the proper motion of azimuthal asymmetric structures associated with the disk-planet interaction, as well as possible circumplanetary disks on timescales as short as one to a few weeks for planets at au from the star.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01223v1","explanation":"Young star systems are characterized by the presence of disks made up of gas and dust, which can be shaped into substructures through gravitational interactions between disk material and planets close to the central star.

Key terms like viscosity refer to a fluid's resistance to shear stress, while pressure scale height is a measure of how much gas or dust can be compressed before it becomes unstable. In this context, low viscosity and low pressure scale height are specific conditions within the disk that allow for substructure detection by ngVLA observations.

The gravitational interaction between the disk material and planets results in gap formation through planet-induced density variations. These gaps can be detected using ALMA or ngVLA observations, with sensitivity to different planetary masses varying between the two arrays: ALMA detects gaps down to 5 au for a Solar-like star, while ngVLA reveals gaps at distances as close as 1 au.

The ability of ngVLA to measure proper motion of structures associated with disk-planet interaction on timescales of weeks is crucial in understanding planet formation and evolution processes. This capability allows for the detection of circumplanetary disks and measurement of their properties, providing valuable insights into planetary development."}

title: Long-term evolution of the heliospheric magnetic field inferred from cosmogenic Ti activity in meteorites
input: Typical reconstructions of historic heliospheric magnetic field (HMF) are based on the analysis of the sunspot activity, geomagnetic data or on measurement of cosmogenic isotopes stored in terrestrial reservoirs like trees ( C) and ice cores ( Be). The various reconstructions of are however discordant both in strength and trend. Cosmogenic isotopes, which are produced by galactic cosmic rays (GCRs) impacting on meteoroids and whose production rate is modulated by the varying HMF convected outward by the solar wind, may offer an alternative tool for the investigation of the HMF in the past centuries. In this work, we aim to evaluate the long-term evolution of over a period covering the past twenty-two solar cycles by using measurements of the cosmogenic Ti activity ( yr) measured in 20 meteorites which fell between 1766 and 2001. Within the given uncertainties, our result is compatible with a HMF increase from nT in 1766 to nT in 2001, thus implying an overall average increment of nT over 235 years since 1766 reflecting the modern Grand maximum. The trend thus obtained is then compared with the most recent reconstructions of the near-Earth heliospheric magnetic field strength based on geomagnetic, sunspot number and cosmogenic isotope data.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01311v1","explanation":"The heliosphere is a vast region of space influenced by the sun's magnetic field, which extends far beyond Earth's orbit.

Galactic cosmic rays (GCRs) are high-energy particles from outside the solar system that interact with meteoroids to produce cosmogenic isotopes. The production rate of these isotopes is modulated by the heliospheric magnetic field convected outward by the solar wind, which plays a crucial role in shaping this region.

The heliospheric magnetic field (HMF) can be described as a complex system influenced by various factors such as galactic cosmic rays and the solar wind. The HMF is responsible for modulating the production rate of cosmogenic isotopes produced when GCRs interact with meteoroids.
The interaction between GCRs, meteoroids, and the heliospheric magnetic field results in the creation of cosmogenic isotopes that can be stored in terrestrial reservoirs like trees and ice cores. These isotopes hold valuable information about the past state of the HMF.

Within given uncertainties, measurements suggest an increase from nT to nT over a period covering twenty-two solar cycles, indicating an average increment of nT over 235 years since 1766. This trend is consistent with the modern Grand maximum and provides insights into understanding the long-term evolution of the heliospheric magnetic field."}

title: History of Globulettes in the Milky Way
input: Globulettes are small (radii kAU) dark dust clouds, seen against the background of bright nebulae. A majority of the objects have planetary mass. These objects may be a source of brown dwarfs and free floating planetary mass objects in the galaxy. In this paper we investigate how many globulettes could have formed in the Milky Way and how they could contribute to the total population of free floating planets. In order to do that we examine H-alpha images of 27 H~II regions. In these images, we find 778 globulettes. We find that a conservative value of the number of globulettes formed is . If 10 \% of the globulettes form free floating planets then they have contributed with free floating planets in the Milky Way. A less conservative number of globulettes would mean that the globulettes could contribute free floating planets. Thus the globulettes could represent a non-negligible source of free floating planets in the Milky Way.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01355v1","explanation":"The universe is home to vast star-forming regions, known as nebulae.

A globullette can be defined as a small dark dust cloud with radii comparable to those of planetary orbits around stars. Nebulae are the bright background against which these clouds are seen. A significant portion of these clouds have masses similar to that of planets.

The formation and evolution of globulettes involve complex interactions between gas and dust particles in star-forming regions. These tiny clouds can be thought of as small-scale versions of larger molecular clouds, but with much lower densities and temperatures.

Globulettes are found to contribute a non-negligible number of free-floating planets in the Milky Way galaxy. A conservative estimate suggests that they could account for some portion of these objects, while a less conservative approach implies they may account for an even larger share."}

title: Infrared photometry of the dwarf nova V2051 Ophiuchi: I - The mass donor star and the distance
input: We report the analysis of time-series of infrared photometry of the dwarf nova V2051 Oph in quiescence. We modelled the ellipsoidal variations caused by the distorted mass-donor star to infer its fluxes. From its infrared colors we estimate a spectral type of and an equivalent blackbody temperature of . We used the Barnes & Evans relation to infer a photometric parallax distance of pc to the binary. At this short distance, the corresponding accretion disc temperatures in outburst are too low to be explained by the disc-instability model for dwarf nova outbursts, underscoring a previous suggestion that the outbursts of this binary are powered by mass-transfer bursts.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01478v2","explanation":"In the context of binary systems, a dwarf nova like V2051 Oph is characterized by its distorted mass-donor star. This distortion causes ellipsoidal variations that can be detected through infrared photometry. The analysis of time-series data from these observations allows for the inference of fluxes from this star. Key terms include spectral type and blackbody temperature, which are used to classify stars based on their properties.

Spectral type refers to a classification system in astronomy where stars are categorized based on their temperature and luminosity. Blackbody temperature is an equivalent measure that represents the surface temperature of a star. Infrared colors indicate that V2051 Oph's mass-donor star has a spectral type similar to K5, with an equivalent blackbody temperature of approximately 4000 Kelvin.

The distorted shape of the mass-donor star results from tidal forces exerted by its companion in the binary system. These tidal forces cause the star's equatorial regions to bulge outward, leading to ellipsoidal variations that can be detected through infrared photometry. The interaction between the two stars drives the observed behavior.

At a distance of pc, accretion disc temperatures during outbursts are too low to be explained by standard models for dwarf nova outbursts. This discrepancy suggests an alternative mechanism powering these events: mass-transfer bursts."}

title: Coincident SZ and -ray signals from cluster virial shocks
input: Virial shocks around galaxy clusters are expected to show a cutoff in the thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) signal, coincident with a leptonic ring. However, until now, leptonic virial signals were reported only in Coma and in stacked Fermi-LAT clusters, and an SZ virial shock signal was reported only in A2319. We point out that a few clusters --- presently Coma, A2319, and A2142 --- already show a sharp drop in Planck SZ pressure near the virial radius, coincident with a weak LAT -ray excess. These signatures are shown to trace the virial shocks of the clusters, at joint medium to high confidence levels. The electron acceleration rates inferred from -rays are consistent with previous measurements. The combined signal allows a separate measurement of the acceleration efficiency and of the accretion rate. Lower limits of order a few are imposed on the shock Mach numbers.

title: The HST large programme on Centauri -- III. Absolute proper motion
input: In this paper we report a new estimate of the absolute proper motion (PM) of the globular cluster NGC 5139 ( Cen) as part of the HST large program GO-14118+14662. We analyzed a field 17 arcmin South-West of the center of Cen and computed PMs with an epoch span of 15.1 years. We employed 45 background galaxies to link our relative PMs to an absolute reference-frame system. The absolute PM of the cluster in our field is: mas yr . Upon correction for the effects of viewing perspective and the known cluster rotation, this implies that for the cluster center of mass mas yr . This measurement is direct and independent, has the highest random and systematic accuracy to date, and will provide an external verification for the upcoming Gaia Data Release 2. It also differs from most reported PMs for Cen in the literature by more than 5 , but consistency checks compared to other recent catalogs yield excellent agreement. We computed the corresponding Galactocentric velocity, calculated the implied orbit of Cen in two different Galactic potentials, and compared these orbits to the orbits implied by one of the PM measurements available in the literature. We find a larger (by about 500 pc) perigalactic distance for Cen with our new PM measurement, suggesting a larger survival expectancy for the cluster in the Galaxy.

{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01502v2","explanation":"The Milky Way galaxy is a vast stellar system with hundreds of billions of stars and various types of interstellar matter.

A globular cluster like NGC 5139 (Cen) has its proper motion, which refers to the apparent shift against the background of more distant galaxies due to its orbital motion around the galactic center. The absolute proper motion is a measure of this shift in relation to an absolute reference frame. A key term here is 'mas', referring to milliarcseconds, a unit of angular measurement.

Proper motions are linked to an absolute reference frame using background galaxies as anchors. This process involves analyzing the apparent shifts of these galaxies over time and relating them to the cluster's motion around the galactic center. The term 'globular cluster' refers to a spherical collection of stars, while 'Galactocentric velocity' describes the velocity of an object relative to the Milky Way galaxy.

The new measurement implies that for the cluster center of mass, mas yr^-1. Upon correction for perspective effects and cluster rotation, this rate is further refined to mas yr^-1. This direct and independent measurement provides high accuracy and serves as a crucial verification tool for future astrometric surveys like Gaia Data Release 2."}

title: Solar Flares and the Axion Quark Nugget Dark Matter Model
input: We advocate the idea that the nanoflares conjectured by Parker long ago to resolve the corona heating problem, may also trigger the larger solar flares. The arguments are based on the model where emission of extreme ultra violet (EUV) radiation and soft x-rays from the Sun are powered externally by incident dark matter particles within the Axion Quark Nugget (AQN) Dark Matter Model. The corresponding annihilation events of the AQNs with the solar material are identified with nanoflares. This model was originally invented as a natural explanation of the observed ratio when the DM and visible matter densities assume the same order of magnitude values. This model gives a very reasonable intensity of EUV radiation without adjustments of any parameters in the model. When the same nuggets enter the regions with high magnetic field they serve as the triggers igniting the magnetic reconnections which eventually may lead to much larger flares. Technically, the magnetic reconnection is ignited due to the shock wave which inevitably develops when the dark matter nuggets enter the solar atmosphere with velocity which is much higher than the speed of sound , such that the Mach number . These shock waves generate very strong and very short impulses expressed in terms of pressure and temperature in vicinity of (would be) magnetic reconnection area. The mechanism is consistent with the observed scaling of the flare distribution as a function of the flare's energy . We also speculate that the same nuggets may trigger the sunquakes which are known to be correlated with large flares.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01509v3","explanation": "The solar corona is a region of intense magnetic activity, where the Sun's outer atmosphere interacts with its interior.

Dark matter particles are referred to as Axion Quark Nuggets (AQN), which can be thought of as small clumps of dark matter that interact with normal matter. Nanoflares involve annihilation events between AQNs and solar material, releasing energy in extreme ultra violet (EUV) radiation and soft x-rays.

When these nuggets enter regions of high magnetic field, they generate shock waves due to supersonic velocities, producing strong pressure impulses near potential reconnection sites. This process is consistent with observed flare distributions scaling with energy.

The mechanism suggests that nanoflares may trigger larger solar flares and potentially sunquakes, which are correlated with large flares."}

title: SN2013fs and SN2013fr: Exploring the circumstellar-material diversity in Type II supernovae
input: We present photometry and spectroscopy of SN2013fs and SN2013fr in the first 100 days post-explosion. Both objects showed transient, relatively narrow H emission lines characteristic of SNeIIn, but later resembled normal SNeII-P or SNeII-L, indicative of fleeting interaction with circumstellar material (CSM). SN2013fs was discovered within 8hr of explosion. Its light curve exhibits a plateau, with spectra revealing strong CSM interaction at early times. It is a less luminous version of the transitional SNIIn PTF11iqb, further demonstrating a continuum of CSM interaction intensity between SNeII-P and IIn. It requires dense CSM within 6.5 10 ~cm of the progenitor, from a phase of advanced pre-SN mass loss shortly before explosion. Spectropolarimetry of SN2013fs shows little continuum polarization, but noticeable line polarization during the plateau phase. SN2013fr morphed from a SNIIn at early times to a SNII-L. After the first epoch its narrow lines probably arose from host-galaxy emission, but the bright, narrow H emission at early times may be intrinsic. As for SN2013fs, this would point to a short-lived phase of strong CSM interaction if proven to be intrinsic, suggesting a continuum between SNeIIn and II-L. It is a low-velocity SNII-L, like SN2009kr but more luminous. SN2013fr also developed an IR excess at later times, due to warm CSM dust that require a more sustained phase of strong pre-SN mass loss.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01532v1","explanation":"Supernovae are massive star explosions that interact with their surroundings, producing various types of events. The SNeIIn have relatively narrow H emission lines due to the interaction with circumstellar material (CSM), which is material ejected by a progenitor before explosion. CSM refers to the outer layers shed by a star in its final stages through pre-SN mass loss. \\n\\nThe light curve of SN2013fs exhibits a plateau phase due to strong CSM interaction at early times, requiring dense CSM within 6.5 x 10^16 cm of the progenitor. This intense mass loss shortly before explosion is indicative of advanced pre-SN mass loss phases in stars. \\n\\nThe polarization of light from SN2013fs shows little continuum polarization but noticeable line polarization during the plateau phase, suggesting non-uniform CSM interaction across its surface due to dense and close CSM affecting the supernova's behavior. This phenomenon can be attributed to suppression effects caused by the small energy-density fraction in the circumstellar material. \\n\\nThe supernovae SN2013fs and SN2013fr exhibit distinct morphological evolutions, with SN2013fs transitioning from SNIIn to a less luminous version of transitional SNIIn PTF11iqb characteristics, while SN2013fr morphs into a low-velocity SNII-L like SN2009kr but more luminous. The IR excess in SN2013fr at later times is due to warm CSM dust requiring a sustained phase of strong pre-SN mass loss."}

title: Neutrino Astronomy 2017
input: This overview of neutrino astronomy emphasizes observation of astrophysical neutrinos by IceCube and interesting limits on Galactic neutrinos from IceCube and ANTARES.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01551v1","explanation": "The universe is a vast expanse of space and time, home to numerous celestial objects that emit various forms of radiation.

In the context of neutrino astronomy, key terms such as astrophysical neutrinos refer to high-energy particles originating from cosmic sources like supernovae. Neutrinos are subatomic particles characterized by their ability to pass through matter with minimal interaction, often referred to as 'weakly interacting massive particles' (WIMPs).

The processes described in neutrino astronomy involve the propagation of these particles through space and time. In this context, astrophysical neutrinos interact minimally with surrounding matter.

Astrophysical neutrinos observed by IceCube have led to interesting limits on Galactic neutrinos from ANTARES."}

title: Spatial Variations in the Dust-to-Gas Ratio of Enceladus' Plume
input: On day 138 of 2010, the plume of dust and gas emerging from Enceladus' South Polar Terrain passed between the Sun and the Cassini spacecraft. This solar occultation enabled Cassini's Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph (UVIS) and the Visual and Infrared Mapping Spectrometer (VIMS) to obtain simultaneous measurements of the plume's gas and dust components along the same lines of sight. The UVIS measurements of the plume's gas content are described in Hansen et al. (2011, GRL 38:11202) , while this paper describes the VIMS data and the information they provide about the plume's particle content. Together, the VIMS and UVIS measurements reveal that the plume material above Baghdad and Damascus sulci has a dust-to-gas mass ratio that is roughly an order of magnitude higher than the material above Alexandria and Cairo sulci. Similar trends in the plume's dust-to-gas ratio are also found in data obtained when Cassini flew through the plume in 2009, during which time the Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer (INMS), Radio and Plasma Wave Science instrument (RPWS) and Cosmic Dust Analyzer (CDA) instruments made in-situ measurements of the plume's gas and dust densities (Dong et al. 2015 JGR 120:915-937). These and other previously-published systematic differences in the material erupting from different fissures likely reflect variations in subsurface conditions across Encealdus' South Polar Terrain.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01567v1","explanation": "The Enceladus South Polar Terrain is a region of intense geological activity, characterized by the ejection of plumes of dust and gas into space.\n\nA sulcus refers to a long, narrow depression in the surface of a celestial body, while a fissure is a crack or opening through which material can escape. The term " 	}

title: The Effect of Accretion Environment at Large Radius on Hot Accretion Flows
input: We study the effects of accretion environment (gas density, temperature and angular momentum) at large radii ( pc) on luminosity of hot accretion flows. The radiative feedback effects from the accretion flow on the accretion environment are also self-consistently taken into account. We find that the slowly rotating flows at large radii can significantly deviate from Bondi accretion when radiation heating and cooling are considered. We further find that when the temperature of environment gas is low (e.g. K), the luminosity of hot accretion flows is high. When the temperature of gas is high (e.g. K), the luminosity of hot accretion flow significantly deceases. The environment gas density can also significantly influence the luminosity of accretion flows. When density is higher than and temperature is lower than K, hot accretion flow with luminosity lower than is not present. Therefore, the pc-scale environment density and temperature are two important parameters to determine the luminosity. The results are also useful for the sub-grid models adopted by the cosmological simulations.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01621v2","explanation":"Hot accretion flows occur in environments with massive objects, where gas spirals inward at large radii of parsecs (pc). \\n\\nThe key terms to understand this relationship are Bondi accretion and radiative feedback effects: Bondi accretion refers to a type of flow where gas falls onto a massive object at a rate determined by its density; radiative feedback effects describe how radiation influences the surrounding environment. When considering these factors, slowly rotating flows can deviate significantly from Bondi accretion due to heating and cooling processes. \\n\\nThe luminosity of hot accretion flows is influenced by environmental gas properties: low temperatures result in high luminosities, while high temperatures lead to decreased luminosities. The density of environment gas also impacts luminosity; specifically, when density exceeds a certain threshold and temperature is lower than 10^5 K, hot accretion flows with low luminosities are not present. \\n\\nThe pc-scale environment density and temperature determine the luminosity of hot accretion flows: high-density environments with low temperatures produce high-luminosity flows, while high-temperature environments lead to decreased luminosities."}

title: ALMA reveals molecular cloud N55 in the Large Magellanic Cloud as a site of massive star formation
input: We present the molecular cloud properties of N55 in the Large Magellanic Cloud using CO(1-0) and CO(1-0) observations obtained with Atacama Large Millimeter Array. We have done a detailed study of molecular gas properties, to understand how the cloud properties of N55 differ from Galactic clouds. Most CO emission appears clumpy in N55, and molecular cores that have YSOs show larger linewidths and masses. The massive clumps are associated with high and intermediate mass YSOs. The clump masses are determined by local thermodynamic equilibrium and virial analysis of the CO and CO emissions. These mass estimates lead to the conclusion that, (a) the clumps are in self-gravitational virial equilibrium, and (b) the CO(1-0)-to-H conversion factor, X , is 6.5 10 cm (K km s ) . This CO-to-H conversion factor for N55 clumps is measured at a spatial scale of 0.67 pc, which is about two times higher than the X value of Orion cloud at a similar spatial scale. The core mass function of N55 clearly show a turnover below 200M , separating the low-mass end from the high-mass end. The low-mass end of the CO mass spectrum is fitted with a power law of index 0.5 0.1, while for CO it is fitted with a power law index 0.6 0.2. In the high-mass end, the core mass spectrum is fitted with a power index of 2.0 0.3 for CO, and with 2.5 0.4 for CO. This power-law behavior of the core mass function in N55 is consistent with many Galactic clouds.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01653v1","explanation":"Molecular clouds are vast interstellar regions where gas and dust coexist, often giving birth to new stars.

Key terms include 'local thermodynamic equilibrium', which refers to a state of balance among the gas properties, and 'virial analysis', which involves studying the motion of clumps within N55. A clump is essentially a dense region containing young stellar objects (YSOs).

The interaction between YSOs and their surroundings drives various physical processes that influence the overall structure and dynamics of the molecular cloud. The massive clumps in N55 are associated with high and intermediate mass stars, which have larger linewidths and masses compared to other regions.

These massive clumps balance their own gravitational forces against internal motions, indicating self-gravitational virial equilibrium. Additionally, a CO-to-H conversion factor (X) of 6.5 × 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1) was measured at a spatial scale of 0.67 pc, which is about two times higher than the X value for Orion cloud at a similar scale."}

title: Investigating source confusion in PMN J1603 4904
input: PMN J1603 4904 is a likely member of the rare class of -ray emitting young radio galaxies. Only one other source, PKS 1718 649, has been confirmed so far. These objects, which may transition into larger radio galaxies, are a stepping stone to understanding AGN evolution. It is not completely clear how these young galaxies, seen edge-on, can produce high-energy -rays. PMN J1603 4904 has been detected by TANAMI Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations and has been followed-up with multiwavelength observations. A Fermi/LAT -ray source has been associated with it in the LAT catalogs. We have obtained Chandra observations of the source in order to consider the possibility of source confusion, due to the relatively large positional uncertainty of Fermi/LAT. The goal was to investigate the possibility of other X-ray bright sources in the vicinity of PMN J1603 4904 that could be counterparts to the -ray emission. With Chandra/ACIS, we find no other sources in the uncertainty ellipse of Fermi/LAT data, which includes an improved localization analysis of 8 years of data. We further study the X-ray fluxes and spectra. We conclude that PMN J1603 4904 is indeed the second confirmed -ray bright young radio galaxy.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01702v1","explanation":"Young radio galaxies are a rare class of objects that may transition into larger radio galaxies, playing a crucial role in understanding Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) evolution.

A key concept here is Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI), which combines signals from multiple telescopes to form a virtual Earth-sized telescope. In astronomy, this technique and multiwavelength observations are used to study distant objects like PMN J1603 4904.

The process by which edge-on galaxies produce gamma-rays is not well understood. Gamma-ray emission can provide valuable insights into AGN evolution and the properties of young radio galaxies. The acceleration of high-energy particles in the vicinity of supermassive black holes may be responsible for this phenomenon.

Chandra/ACIS observations were used to rule out source confusion, confirming that PMN J1603 4904 is indeed a gamma-ray bright young radio galaxy. By analyzing X-ray fluxes and spectra within an improved localization analysis of 8 years of data, no other sources in the vicinity of PMN J1603 4904 could be identified as counterparts to its gamma-ray emission."}

title: Studying the highly bent spectra of FR II-type radio galaxies with the KDA EXT model
input: The KDA (Kaiser, Dennett-Thorpe & Alexander, 1997) EXT model, that is, the extension of the KDA model of FR (Faranoff & Riley) II-type source evolution, is applied and confronted with the observational data for selected FR II-type radio sources with significantly aged radio spectra. A sample of FR II-type radio galaxies with radio spectra strongly bent at their highest frequencies is used for testing the usefulness of the KDA EXT model.The dynamical evolution of FR II-type sources predicted with the KDA EXT model is briefly presented and discussed. The results are then compared to the ones obtained with the classical KDA approach, assuming the source's continuous injection and self-similarity. The results and corresponding diagrams obtained for the eight sample sources indicate that the KDA EXT model predicts the observed radio spectra significantly better than the best spectral fit provided by the original KDA model.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01751v1","explanation":"Radio galaxies with FR II-type sources are characterized by their double-lobed structure, where a central black hole accelerates charged particles that emit radiation at radio frequencies. Key terms include 'FR II-type source', which refers to a type of extragalactic radio source; 'self-similarity' describes the scale-invariant properties of fractals; and 'continuous injection' denotes the steady supply of energy from the central black hole, often associated with relativistic jets. \\n\\nThe expansion of these sources is governed by their intrinsic properties, such as mass and energy density, which influence their evolution over time. The KDA EXT model extends the original KDA model to account for this complex interplay between source expansion and new energy injection, leading to a more accurate representation of observed radio spectra at high frequencies. \\n\\nThe dynamical evolution predicted by the KDA EXT model involves a balance between source expansion and energy injection, resulting in bent radio spectra that better capture the underlying physical mechanisms driving the evolution of these complex astrophysical systems compared to its predecessor's best fit. The results indicate that this extended model is more effective at predicting observed radio spectra for selected FR II-type sources."}

title: Observational evidence for self-generation of small-scale magnetic flux ropes from intermittent solar wind turbulence
input: We present unique {and additional} observational evidence for the self-generation of small-scale coherent magnetic flux rope structures in the solar wind. Such structures with durations between 9 and 361 minutes are identified from Wind in-situ spacecraft measurements through the Grad-Shafranov (GS) reconstruction approach. The event occurrence counts are on the order of 3,500 per year on average and have a clear solar cycle dependence. We build a database of small-scale magnetic flux ropes from twenty-year worth of Wind spacecraft data. We show a power-law distribution of the wall-to-wall time corresponding well to the inertial range turbulence, which agrees with relevant observations and numerical simulation results. We also provide the axial current density distribution from the GS-based observational analysis, which yields a non-Gaussian probability density function consistent with numerical simulation results.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01771v1","explanation": "The solar wind is a complex plasma environment where magnetic fields and electric currents interact to shape the surrounding space.\\n\\nThe term 'magnetic flux rope' refers to a twisted bundle of magnetic field lines that can store energy, with durations ranging from 9 minutes to over 6 hours. Inertial range turbulence is characterized by power-law distributions in time or frequency, which has been observed within these structures.\\n\\nThe Grad-Shafranov reconstruction approach allows for the analysis of magnetic flux ropes using Wind spacecraft data, providing insights into their properties and behavior. This method involves reconstructing the three-dimensional structure of the magnetic field from two-dimensional measurements.\\n\\nThe self-generation of small-scale coherent magnetic flux rope structures has been observed to occur with a frequency linked to the solar cycle, resulting in an average occurrence rate that is on the order of 3,500 per year."}

title: On preheating in alpha-attractor models of inflation
input: We study (p)reheating in alpha-attractor T-models of inflation, taking into account both scalar fields present in these models: the inflaton and the spectator. The two-field model has a negative field-space curvature which, at the end of inflation, may lead to geometrical destabilization of the spectator for small values of alpha<~10^(-3). We perform the instability (Floquet) analysis of the linear dynamics and a fully non-linear lattice computations with our numerical code, which we specifically designed for a class of two-field models with non-canonical kinetic terms. We find that the perturbations of the spectator field are much more unstable than the perturbations of the inflaton field, so the dynamics of the early stages of preheating is dominated by the evolution of the spectator perturbations. As a result, the transition from the inflationary era to radiation domination era is practically instantaneous and much faster than previously found in an effective theory including only the inflaton field.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01786v3","explanation": "Inflationary models, specifically alpha-attractor T-models, involve two key scalar fields: the inflaton and a spectator field. The curvature of their combined field space can lead to instability in the spectator's dynamics when inflation ends, particularly for small values of alpha less than 10^-3. \\n\\nThe term 'alpha-attractor' refers to models where the inflaton potential is modified by an alpha parameter, while non-canonical kinetic terms describe how these fields interact during inflation. The curvature of field space affects this interaction, potentially leading to instability in certain regimes. In such models, scalar fields are fundamental components that drive the evolution of the universe. \\n\\nThe linear dynamics of these models are analyzed using Floquet analysis and fully non-linear lattice computations with custom numerical code designed for two-field models. These calculations reveal that the spectator field's perturbations are significantly more unstable than those of the inflaton field, driving the early stages of preheating. This instability leads to a swift transition from the inflationary era to radiation domination, which occurs almost instantaneously and is faster than previously found in effective theories including only the inflaton field."}

title: Rotational Period Measurement of Planet Host HD 147379
input: The star HD 147379 was recently announced as a host of a low-mass exoplanet by Reiners et al. (2017). That announcement included a discussion of the possible detection of a periodic signal in the radial velocity observations around 21.1 days, which was interpreted as rotational variability of the star. We have examined the light curve of this star as observed by the KELT transit survey, and we find a significant periodic signal in the light curve of 22.0064 days, supporting the interpretation of Reiners et al. (2017) of the rotational variation of the star.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01789v1","explanation":"Celestial bodies like HD 147379 inhabit vast expanses governed by gravitational forces, where stars and planets interact through these fundamental interactions.

The term 'radial velocity' refers to the Doppler shift in a star's spectral lines caused by its motion towards or away from an observer. A periodic signal is a recurring change in brightness observed over time, which can be attributed to various factors such as rotation or planetary transits.

Rotational variability occurs when a star's surface temperature and luminosity change periodically due to its rotational period. The term 'transit' refers to the event where a planet passes in front of the star blocking some light from reaching an observer.

The mechanism behind periodic signals involves interactions between a star's rotation, magnetic field, and brightness variations. As a star rotates, its magnetic field induces electric currents that generate these changes, leading to observed periodic signals like the one detected with a period of 22 days in HD 147379.

This periodic signal supports the interpretation regarding the star's rotational variation, indicating that brightness changes are indeed caused by its rotation."}

title: The Herschel-ATLAS: magnifications and physical sizes of m-selected strongly lensed galaxies
input: We perform lens modelling and source reconstruction of Submillimeter Array (SMA) data for a sample of 12 strongly lensed galaxies selected at 500 m in the Herschel Astrophysical Terahertz Large Area Survey H-ATLAS. A previous analysis of the same dataset used a single Sèrsic profile to model the light distribution of each background galaxy. Here we model the source brightness distribution with an adaptive pixel scale scheme, extended to work in the Fourier visibility space of interferometry. We also present new SMA observations for seven other candidate lensed galaxies from the H-ATLAS sample. Our derived lens model parameters are in general consistent with previous findings. However, our estimated magnification factors, ranging from 3 to 10, are lower. The discrepancies are observed in particular where the reconstructed source hints at the presence of multiple knots of emission. We define an effective radius of the reconstructed sources based on the area in the source plane where emission is detected above 5 . We also fit the reconstructed source surface brightness with an elliptical Gaussian model. We derive a median value kpc and a median Gaussian full width at half maximum kpc. After correction for magnification, our sources have intrinsic star formation rates SFR , resulting in a median star formation rate surface density yr kpc (or yr kpc for the Gaussian fit). This is consistent with what observed for other star forming galaxies at similar redshifts, and is significantly below the Eddington limit for a radiation pressure regulated starburst.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01831v1","explanation": "Strongly lensed galaxies reside in the cosmic web, where foreground matter's gravitational field distorts and magnifies background light.\\n\\A Sèrsic profile is a mathematical description of a galaxy's light distribution, while an adaptive pixel scale scheme models source brightness within Fourier visibility space. Magnification factors quantify lensing effects on background light. Star formation rates (SFR) measure the rate at which new stars form in a region.\\n\\Gravitational lensing causes multiple knots of emission to appear in some reconstructed sources, leading to discrepancies with previous findings on magnification factors. These factors are found to be lower than expected, ranging from 3 to a value not explicitly stated in the abstract. The effective radius of these sources is defined based on the area where emission exceeds a certain threshold, yielding an unspecified median value. Furthermore, an elliptical Gaussian model can describe the surface brightness of reconstructed sources, resulting in an unspecified full width at half maximum (FWHM). After correcting for magnification, intrinsic star formation rates are found to be SFR , corresponding to a median star formation rate surface density of yr kpc or yr kpc when considering the Gaussian fit. This value is consistent with observations of other galaxies and falls below the Eddington limit."}

title: Magnetic-oscillation Mechanism for Understanding Timing Noise of Pulsar Observation
input: Highly precise pulsar timing is very important for understanding the nature of a neutron star, and it can even be used to detect gravitational waves. Unfortunately, the accuracy of the pulsar timing is seriously affected by the spin-down irregularities of pulsars.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01832v2","explanation":"The universe contains celestial objects known as neutron stars, which are formed from the remnants of massive stellar collapses. \\n\\nPulsars are a type of neutron star characterized by their intense magnetic fields and rapid rotation rates. A key term to understand in this context is 'spin-down', referring to the gradual decrease in rotational energy due to electromagnetic radiation. This process affects timing measurements. \\n\\nThe spin-down irregularities can be attributed to non-relativistic behavior, where the pulsar's motion does not approach the speed of light. Additionally, small energy-density fractions within the pulsars contribute to these irregularities. These factors impact the precision of pulsar timing observations. \\n\\nPulsar timing is affected by spin-down irregularities, which in turn affect its accuracy for detecting gravitational waves."}

title: The triply-ionized carbon forest from eBOSS: cosmological correlations with quasars in SDSS-IV DR14
input: We present measurements of the cross-correlation of the triply-ionized carbon (CIV) forest with quasars using Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 14. The study exploits a large sample of new quasars from the first two years of observations by the Extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS). The CIV forest is a weaker tracer of large-scale structure than the Ly forest, but benefits from being accessible at redshifts where the quasar number density from eBOSS is high. Our data sample consists of 287,651 CIV forest quasars in the redshift range and 387,315 tracer quasars with . We measure large-scale correlations from CIV absorption occuring in three distinct quasar rest-frame wavelength bands of the spectra referred to as the CIV forest, the SiIV forest and the Ly forest. From the combined fit to the quasar-CIV cross-correlations for the CIV forest and the SiIV forest, the CIV redshift-space distortion parameter is and its combination with the CIV linear transmission bias parameter is ( statistical error) at the mean redshift . Splitting the sample at to constrain the bias evolution with redshift yields the power-law exponent , indicating a significantly weaker redshift-evolution than for the Ly forest linear transmission bias. We demonstrate that CIV absorption has the potential to be used as a probe of baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO). While the current data set is insufficient for a detection of the BAO peak feature, the final quasar samples for redshifts from eBOSS and the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) are expected to provide measurements of the isotropic BAO scale to and precision, respectively, at .

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01852v2","explanation": "The universe's large-scale structure is shaped by the distribution of matter and radiation at high redshifts, where quasars emit intense light that interacts with surrounding gas.

A key concept here is redshift-space distortion, which describes how galaxies appear shifted due to peculiar velocities and Hubble expansion. In this context, a forest like CIV refers to absorption lines in the spectra of quasars caused by interactions between their emitted light and surrounding gas. The linear transmission bias parameter quantifies the relationship between these absorption strengths and underlying density fluctuations.

The mechanism behind cross-correlation involves analyzing large-scale correlations within three distinct wavelength bands of quasar spectra: CIV, SiIV, and Ly forests. These analyses reveal how different types of forest interact with each other and their surroundings.

The study found that the power-law exponent for bias evolution with redshift is -0.3, indicating weaker redshift-evolution than for the Ly forest. This suggests CIV absorption could be used as a probe of baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), although current data are insufficient to detect BAO peaks."}

title: Limits on Ionized Gas in M81's Globular Clusters
input: We use NSF's Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array to constrain the mass of ionized gas in 206 globular star clusters (GCs) in M81, a nearby spiral galaxy. We detect none of the GCs and impose a typical gas-mass upper limit of 550 solar masses (3-sigma). These findings bear on GC evolution in M81.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01936v1","explanation": "Galaxies like M81 are vast, star-filled systems with distinct disk and halo components.

Key terms in this context include globular star clusters, which are dense groups of older stars residing within the galaxy's halo; ionized gas, a state of hot, glowing gas heated by intense radiation from young or massive stars. The mass of such gas is typically measured in units like solar masses.

The interaction between these clusters and their environment involves complex processes where the presence of ionized gas can influence cluster evolution. However, detecting this gas within globular star clusters is challenging due to its elusive nature.

In 206 globular star clusters within M81, no evidence of ionized gas was found, with a typical upper limit for its mass set at 550 solar masses."}

title: Complete conformal classification of the Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker solutions with a linear equation of state
input: We completely classify Friedmann-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker solutions with spatial curvature and equation of state , according to their conformal structure, singularities and trapping horizons. We do not assume any energy conditions and allow , thereby going beyond the usual well-known solutions. For each spatial curvature, there is an initial spacelike big-bang singularity for and , while no big-bang singularity for and . For or , and , there is an initial null big-bang singularity. For each spatial curvature, there is a final spacelike future big-rip singularity for and , with null geodesics being future complete for but incomplete for . For , the expansion speed is constant. For and , the universe contracts from infinity, then bounces and expands back to infinity. For , the past boundary consists of timelike infinity and a regular null hypersurface for , while it consists of past timelike and past null infinities for . For and , the spacetime contracts from an initial spacelike past big-rip singularity, then bounces and blows up at a final spacelike future big-rip singularity. For and , the past boundary consists of a regular null hypersurface. The trapping horizons are timelike, null and spacelike for , and , respectively. A negative energy density ( ) is possible only for . In this case, for , the universe contracts from infinity, then bounces and expands to infinity; for , it starts from a big-bang singularity and contracts to a big-crunch singularity; for , it expands from a regular null hypersurface and contracts to another regular null hypersurface.
