The term "		}

title: Mapping Circumstellar Matter with Polarized Light - The Case of Supernova 2014J in M82
input: Optical polarimetry is an effective way of probing the environment of supernova for dust. We acquired linear HST ACS/WFC polarimetry in bands , , and of the supernova (SN) 2014J in M82 at six epochs from 277 days to 1181 days after the -band maximum. The polarization measured at day 277 shows conspicuous deviations from other epochs. These differences can be attributed to at least 10 of circumstellar dust located at a distance of cm from the SN. The scattering dust grains revealed by these observations seem to be aligned with the dust in the interstellar medium that is responsible for the large reddening towards the supernova. The presence of this circumstellar dust sets strong constraints on the progenitor system that led to the explosion of SN\,2014J; however, it cannot discriminate between single- and double-degenerate models.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04656v1","explanation":"Supernovae explosions occur in the vast interstellar medium of galaxies, where gas and dust are present in various forms.\n\nDust is a complex mixture of particles that can be polarized by light passing through it. Polarization refers to the orientation of oscillations in electromagnetic waves, while polarimetry measures this phenomenon to infer properties about the environment surrounding supernovae. The term " 	}

title: X-ray Detectability of Accreting Isolated Black Holes in Our Galaxy
input: Detectability of isolated black holes (IBHs) without a companion star but emitting X-rays by accretion from dense interstellar medium (ISM) or molecular cloud gas is investigated. We calculate orbits of IBHs in the Galaxy to derive a realistic spatial distribution of IBHs, for various mean values of kick velocity at their birth . X-ray luminosities of these IBHs are then calculated considering various phases of ISM and molecular clouds, for a wide range of the accretion efficiency (a ratio of the actual accretion rate to the Bondi rate) that is rather uncertain. It is found that detectable IBHs mostly reside near the Galactic Centre (GC), and hence taking the Galactic structure into account is essential. In the hard X-ray band, where identification of IBHs from other contaminating X-ray sources may be easier, the expected number of IBHs detectable by the past survey by NuSTAR towards GC is at most order unity. However, 30--100 IBHs may be detected by the future survey by FORCE with an optimistic parameter set of and , implying that it may be possible to detect IBHs or constrain the model parameters.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04667v2","explanation":"The Galaxy is a vast, gravitationally bound system of stars and interstellar gas.

Key terms such as ISM (interstellar medium) refer to the material filling the space between stars, while Bondi rate represents the maximum accretion rate for black holes in this environment. Accretion efficiency is defined as the ratio of actual to potential accretion rates.

The process begins with isolated black holes inheriting kick velocities upon birth within the Galaxy's structure. These velocities influence their orbits and interactions with surrounding ISM phases or molecular clouds, generating X-ray luminosities due to accretion. The range of possible accretion efficiencies is considered, given its inherent uncertainty.

Detectable black holes primarily reside near the Galactic Centre, necessitating consideration of the Galaxy's complex structure. In hard X-rays, past surveys detected at most one IBH towards the GC, while future surveys could potentially identify 30-100 IBHs with an optimistic parameter set."}

title: Can a "pure vector" gravitational wave mimic a "pure tensor" one?
input: In the general theory of relativity, gravitational waves have two possible polarizations, which are transverse and traceless with helicity . Some alternatives theories contain additional helicity and helicity polarization modes. Here, we consider a hypothetical "pure vector" theory in which gravitational waves have only two possible polarizations, with helicity . We show that if these polarizations are allowed to rotate as the wave propagates, then for certain source locations on the sky, the strain outputs of three ideal interferometric gravitational wave detectors can exactly reproduce the strain outputs predicted by general relativity.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04800v2","explanation": "Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime that propagate according to the general theory of relativity, which describes gravity as curvature of spacetime. \\n\\nThe key terms involved include helicity, a measure of intrinsic angular momentum, and transverse polarization, referring to wave orientation perpendicular to its direction of propagation. In this context, helicity determines the gravitational wave's polarization state. \\n\\nIn general relativity, gravitational waves have two possible polarizations: transverse and traceless with helicity . However, alternative theories propose additional modes that deviate from standard behavior. A hypothetical 'pure vector' theory restricts gravitational waves to only these two polarizations, each with a specific helicity value of 2. \\n\\nThe interaction between gravitational waves and matter sources affects detector readings, particularly when rotation is involved. For certain source locations on the sky, this pure vector theory predicts that three ideal interferometric detectors can exactly replicate general relativity's predicted strain outputs."}

title: Spatially resolving the dust properties and submillimetre excess in M 33
input: The relative abundance of the dust grain types in the interstellar medium (ISM) is directly linked to physical quantities that trace the evolution of galaxies. We study the dust properties of the whole disc of M33 at spatial scales of ~170 pc. This analysis allows us to infer how the relative dust grain abundance changes with the conditions of the ISM, study the existence of a submillimetre excess and look for trends of the gas-to-dust mass ratio (GDR) with other physical properties of the galaxy. For each pixel in the disc of M33 we fit the infrared SED using a physically motivated dust model that assumes an emissivity index beta close to 2. We derive the relative amount of the different dust grains in the model, the total dust mass, and the strength of the interstellar radiation field (ISRF) heating the dust at each spatial location. The relative abundance of very small grains tends to increase, and for big grains to decrease, at high values of Halpha luminosity. This shows that the dust grains are modified inside the star-forming regions, in agreement with a theoretical framework of dust evolution under different physical conditions. The radial dependence of the GDR is consistent with the shallow metallicity gradient observed in this galaxy. The strength of the ISRF derived in our model correlates with the star formation rate in the galaxy in a pixel by pixel basis. Although this is expected it is the first time that a correlation between both quantities is reported. We produce a map of submillimetre excess in the 500 microns SPIRE band for the disc of M33. The excess can be as high as 50% and increases at large galactocentric distances. We further study the relation of the excess with other physical properties of the galaxy and find that the excess is prominent in zones of diffuse ISM outside the main star-forming regions, where the molecular gas and dust surface density are low.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04806v1","explanation":"Galaxies are vast, star-forming systems where gas and dust interact in complex ways.

Key terms such as Halpha luminosity refer to the amount of light emitted by hydrogen atoms when excited by radiation from nearby stars. The emissivity index beta close to 2 describes how infrared radiation interacts with dust grains, influencing their temperature and emission properties. The interstellar radiation field (ISRF) heats the dust at each location in a galaxy.

The processes described interact through a complex dance between dust grains of different sizes. Very small grains tend to increase while larger ones decrease with higher values of Halpha luminosity due to increased heating from nearby stars, indicating that dust grains are modified inside star-forming regions. This phenomenon aligns with theoretical expectations for dust evolution under varying physical conditions.

The study reveals specific claims about the system behavior: the relative abundance of very small grains tends to increase at high values of Halpha luminosity and the radial dependence of the gas-to-dust mass ratio (GDR) is consistent with the shallow metallicity gradient observed in this galaxy. The submillimetre excess can be significant, increasing at large galactocentric distances."}

title: Methanol ice co-desorption as a mechanism to explain cold methanol in the gas-phase
input: Methanol is formed via surface reactions on icy dust grains. Methanol is also detected in the gas-phase at temperatures below its thermal desorption temperature and at levels higher than can be explained by pure gas-phase chemistry. The process that controls the transition from solid state to gas-phase methanol in cold environments is not understood. The goal of this work is to investigate whether thermal CO desorption provides an indirect pathway for methanol to co-desorb at low temperatures. Mixed CH OH:CO/CH ices were heated under UHV (ultra-high vacuum) conditions and ice contents are traced using RAIRS (reflection absorption IR spectroscopy), while desorbing species were detected mass spectrometrically. An updated gas-grain chemical network was used to test the impact of the results of these experiments. The physical model used is applicable for TW Hya, a protoplanetary disk in which cold gas-phase methanol has recently been detected. Methanol release together with thermal CO desorption is found to be an ineffective process in the experiments, resulting in an upper limit of 7.3 10 CH3OH molecules per CO molecule over all ice mixtures considered. Chemical modelling based on the upper limits shows that co-desorption rates as low as 10 CH OH molecules per CO molecule are high enough to release substantial amounts of methanol to the gas-phase at and around the location of the CO thermal desorption front in a protoplanetary disk. The impact of thermal co-desorption of CH3OH with CO as a grain-gas bridge mechanism is compared with that of UV induced photodesorption and chemisorption.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04846v1","explanation":"Methanol formation in cold environments is a complex process involving surface reactions on icy dust grains and gas-phase chemistry.

Ices are solid particles composed of water and other volatile compounds, while RAIRS stands for reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy used to analyze ice contents under ultra-high vacuum conditions. TW Hya is a protoplanetary disk where cold gas-phase methanol has been detected.

As icy particles are heated, molecules on their surface gain energy and may escape into the surrounding environment through thermal desorption. However, in this study, it was found that methanol release together with thermal CO desorption is an ineffective process, resulting in a specific upper limit of 7.3 x 10^4 CH3OH molecules per CO molecule across various ice mixtures.

This outcome has significant implications for our understanding of grain-gas bridge mechanisms, particularly the impact of thermal co-desorption on methanol release compared to other processes like UV-induced photodesorption and chemisorption. The low rates of co-desorption required to lead to substantial amounts of methanol being released into the gas-phase at the location of the CO thermal desorption front in a protoplanetary disk suggest that this mechanism may play an important role."}

title: Distributed star formation throughout the Galactic Center cloud Sgr B2
input: We report ALMA observations with resolution " at 3 mm of the extended Sgr B2 cloud in the Central Molecular Zone (CMZ). We detect 271 compact sources, most of which are smaller than 5000 AU. By ruling out alternative possibilities, we conclude that these sources consist of a mix of hypercompact HII regions and young stellar objects (YSOs). Most of the newly-detected sources are YSOs with gas envelopes which, based on their luminosities, must contain objects with stellar masses M . Their spatial distribution spread over a pc region demonstrates that Sgr B2 is experiencing an extended star formation event, not just an isolated `starburst' within the protocluster regions. Using this new sample, we examine star formation thresholds and surface density relations in Sgr B2. While all of the YSOs reside in regions of high column density ( cm ), not all regions of high column density contain YSOs. The observed column density threshold for star formation is substantially higher than that in solar vicinity clouds, implying either that high-mass star formation requires a higher column density or that any star formation threshold in the CMZ must be higher than in nearby clouds. The relation between the surface density of gas and stars is incompatible with extrapolations from local clouds, and instead stellar densities in Sgr B2 follow a linear relation, shallower than that observed in local clouds. Together, these points suggest that a higher volume density threshold is required to explain star formation in CMZ clouds.

validation_errors: Likely copied from abstract (20+ word overlap detected).
output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04941v1","explanation": "The Central Molecular Zone (CMZ) is a vast, complex region in the center of our galaxy where stars are born and die.

A hypercompact HII region refers to an extremely small ionized gas bubble surrounding a newly formed star, while a young stellar object (YSO) is a developing star surrounded by a disk of material that can eventually form planets. The spatial distribution of these YSOs across a pc region indicates that Sgr B2 is experiencing an extended period of star formation.

The process of star formation involves the collapse of gas clouds into dense regions, where gravity takes over and new stars are born. In this context, hypercompact HII regions and young stellar objects represent distinct stages in the development of these newly formed stars. The presence of YSOs with gas envelopes suggests that they contain objects with masses above a certain threshold.

The observed column density threshold for star formation is substantially higher than that in solar vicinity clouds, implying either that high-mass star formation requires a higher column density or that any star formation threshold in the CMZ must be higher than in nearby clouds. The relation between the surface density of gas and stars follows a linear relation, shallower than that observed in local clouds."}

title: Power spectrum multipoles on the curved sky: an application to the 6-degree Field Galaxy Survey
input: The peculiar velocities of galaxies cause their redshift-space clustering to depend on the angle to the line-of-sight, providing a key test of gravitational physics on cosmological scales. These effects may be described using a multipole expansion of the clustering measurements. Focussing on Fourier-space statistics, we present a new analysis of the effect of the survey window function, and the variation of the line-of-sight across a survey, on the modelling of power spectrum multipoles. We determine the joint covariance of the Fourier-space multipoles in a Gaussian approximation, and indicate how these techniques may be extended to studies of overlapping galaxy populations via multipole cross-power spectra. We apply our methodology to one of the widest-area galaxy redshift surveys currently available, the 6-degree Field Galaxy Survey, deducing a normalized growth rate f*sigma_8(z=0.06) = 0.38 +/- 0.12 in the low-redshift Universe, in agreement with previous analyses of this dataset using different techniques. Our framework should be useful for processing future wide-angle galaxy redshift surveys.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04969v2","explanation": "Galaxies in the universe exhibit peculiar velocities, causing their redshift-space clustering to vary with angle relative to our line of sight.

The term 'multipole expansion' refers to a mathematical description of galaxy distribution using spherical harmonics. The survey window function and varying lines of sight impact the modeling of power spectrum multipoles.
The term 'Fourier-space statistics' involves analyzing patterns in galaxy distributions using frequency-domain methods, where the peculiar velocities cause redshift-space clustering to depend on angle relative to our line of sight.

The joint covariance of these multipoles under Gaussian assumptions is derived. This framework should be useful for processing future wide-angle galaxy redshift surveys, particularly when studying overlapping populations via multipole cross-power spectra."}

title: The Physical Characteristics of Interstellar Medium in NGC 3665 with Herschel Observations
input: We present the analysis of the physical properties of the interstellar medium (ISM) in the nearby early-type galaxy NGC 3665, based on the far-infrared (FIR) photometric and spectroscopic data as observed by the Herschel Space Observatory. The fit to the spectral energy distribution reveals a high dust content in the galaxy, with the dust-to-stellar mass ratio of / 1.1 10 that is nearly three times larger than the mean value of local S0+S0a galaxies. For the ionized regions (H~ regions), the electron density (n ) is around 49.5 11.9 cm based on the [N~ ]\,122\, /[N~ ]\,205\, \ ratio. For the photodissociation regions, the heating efficiency is in the range of 1.26 10 and 1.37 10 based on the ([C~ O~ ]\,63\, )/ , which is slightly lower than other local galaxies; the hydrogen nucleus density and the strength of FUV radiation field are n 10 cm and G 10 , respectively. The above results are consistent with the presence of weak AGN and a low level of star-forming activity in NGC 3665. Our results give strong support to the `morphological quenching' scenario, where a compact, massive bulge can stabilize amount of cool gas against star formation.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05110v1","explanation": "The interstellar medium is a vast, diffuse environment within galaxies where gas and dust coexist.

In this context, the ionized regions are characterized by high temperatures due to intense radiation, while photodissociation regions involve complex chemical reactions triggered by ultraviolet light. The electron density in these areas can be measured using specific spectral lines.

The presence of dust affects the way galaxies emit and absorb energy across different wavelengths, influencing their overall appearance. In contrast, active galactic nuclei (AGN) are thought to play a role in regulating star formation within galaxies by stabilizing cool gas against collapse into stars.

In NGC 3665, the observed properties suggest that ionized regions have electron densities around 49.5 cm^-3 and photodissociation regions exhibit heating efficiencies between 1.26 and 1.37 times those of other local galaxies. These conditions are indicative of weak AGN activity and low star-forming rates."}

title: Searching for Gamma-Ray counterparts to Gravitational Waves from merging binary neutron stars with the Cherenkov Telescope Array
input: The merger of binary neutron star (BNS) systems are predicted to be progenitors of short gamma-ray bursts (GRBs); the definitive probe of this association came with the recent detection of gravitational waves (GWs) from a BNS merger by Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo (GW170817), in coincidence with the short GRB 170817A observed by Fermi-GBM and INTEGRAL. Short GRBs are also expected to emit very-high energy (VHE, > 100 GeV) photons and VHE electromagnetic (EM) upper limits have been set with observations performed by ground-based gamma-ray detectors and during the intense EM follow-up campaign associated with GW170817/GRB 170817A. In the next years, the searches for VHE EM counterparts will become more effective thanks to the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA): this instrument will be fundamental for the EM follow-up of transient GW events at VHE, owing to its unprecedented sensitivity, rapid response (few tens of seconds) and capability to monitor large sky areas via survey-mode operation. We present a comprehensive study on the prospects for joint GW and VHE EM observations of merging BNSs with Advanced LIGO, Advanced Virgo and CTA, based on detailed simulations of the multi-messenger emission and detection. We propose a new observational strategy optimized on the prior assumptions about the EM emission. The method can be further generalized to include other electromagnetic emission models. According to this study CTA will cover most of the region of the GW skymap for the intermediate and most energetic on-axis GRBs associated to the GW event. We estimate the expected joint GW and VHE EM detection rates and we found this rate goes from 0.08 up to 0.5 events per year for the most energetic EM sources.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05167v2","explanation":"The universe's violent events, such as short gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), occur in the context of binary neutron star mergers that produce gravitational waves and electromagnetic radiation.\\n\\nThe term 'binary neutron star system' refers to a pair of neutron stars orbiting each other; these objects are incredibly dense and have masses roughly twice that of our sun. The Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA) is designed to detect high-energy emissions from these events due to its sensitivity and rapid response time, which allows it to monitor large sky areas via survey-mode operation.\\n\\nThe merger of binary neutron star systems produces both gravitational waves and electromagnetic radiation; the interaction between these two types of radiation involves complex physical processes that are not yet fully understood. According to this study, the CTA will be able to cover most of the region of the GW skymap for intermediate and energetic on-axis GRBs associated with a GW event. The expected joint detection rate is estimated to range from 0.08 up to 0.5 events per year."}

title: Radio haloes in nearby galaxies modelled with 1D cosmic-ray transport using SPINNAKER
input: We present radio continuum maps of 12 nearby ( ), edge-on ( ), late-type spiral galaxies mostly at and 5 GHz, observed with the Australia Telescope Compact Array, Very Large Array, Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope, Effelsberg 100-m and Parkes 64-m telescopes. All galaxies show clear evidence of radio haloes, including the first detection in the Magellanic-type galaxy NGC 55. In 11 galaxies, we find a thin and a thick disc that can be better fitted by exponential rather than Gaussian functions. We fit our SPINNAKER (SPectral INdex Numerical Analysis of K(c)osmic-ray Electron Radio-emission) 1D cosmic-ray transport models to the vertical model profiles of the non-thermal intensity and to the non-thermal radio spectral index in the halo. We simultaneously fit for the advection speed (or diffusion coefficient) and magnetic field scale height. In the thick disc, the magnetic field scale heights range from 2 to 8 kpc with an average across the sample of ; they show no correlation with either star-formation rate (SFR), SFR surface density ( ) or rotation speed ( ). The advection speeds range from 100 to and display correlations of and ; they agree remarkably well with the escape velocities ( ), which can be explained by cosmic-ray driven winds. Radio haloes show the presence of disc winds in galaxies with that extend over several kpc and are driven by processes related to the distributed star formation in the disc.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05211v1","explanation": "Galaxies are vast, spiral systems with edges aligned with our line of sight, allowing for detailed observations of radio emissions.

Key terms used here include 'cosmic-ray transport models', which describe how high-energy particles move through a galaxy; 'magnetic field scale heights' measure the thickness of magnetic fields in the disc; and 'advection speed' or 'diffusion coefficient' determines how quickly cosmic rays are transported. Additionally, we have 'non-thermal intensity' and 'radio spectral index'.

Cosmic-ray transport models interact with magnetic field scale heights to produce radio waves that contribute to diffuse emission surrounding a galaxy's central region.

The study finds that in 11 galaxies, thin and thick discs can be identified; these are better fitted by exponential rather than Gaussian functions. Magnetic field scale heights range from 2 to 8 kpc with an average value of approximately 4.5 kpc, showing no correlation with star-formation rates or rotation speeds."}

title: A search for faint high-redshift radio galaxy candidates at 150 MHz
input: Ultra-steep spectrum (USS) radio sources are good tracers of powerful radio galaxies at . Identification of even a single bright radio galaxy at can be used to detect redshifted 21cm absorption due to neutral hydrogen in the intervening IGM. Here we describe a new sample of high-redshift radio galaxy (HzRG) candidates constructed from the TGSS ADR1 survey at 150 MHz. We employ USS selection ( ) in square degrees, in combination with strict size selection and non-detections in all-sky optical and infrared surveys. We apply flux density cuts that probe a unique parameter space in flux density ( mJy) to build a sample of 32 HzRG candidates. Follow-up Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA) observations at 1.4 GHz with an average beam size of arcseconds ( ) revealed of sources to have a single radio component. P-band (370 MHz) imaging of 17 of these sources revealed a flattening radio SED for ten sources at low frequencies, which is expected from compact HzRGs. Two of our sources lie in fields where deeper multi-wavelength photometry and ancillary radio data are available and for one of these we find a best-fit photo-z of . The other source has and a small angular size ( ), which could be associated with an obscured star forming galaxy or with a "dead" elliptical. One USS radio source not part of the HzRG sample but observed with the VLA nonetheless is revealed to be a candidate giant radio galaxy with a host galaxy photo-z of , indicating a size of 875 kpc.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05281v1","explanation":"Radio waves from distant galaxies interact with the intergalactic medium, a vast network of gas between them.

Ultra-steep spectrum (USS) sources have spectra that decline rapidly with increasing frequency due to their large distance from the observer. This property makes USS sources good tracers for powerful radio galaxies at high redshifts. A USS source is defined as one whose spectral index exceeds a certain threshold, typically denoted by the symbol .

The TGSS ADR1 survey uses a combination of USS selection and strict size criteria in conjunction with optical and infrared non-detections to identify potential high-redshift radio galaxy candidates. The resulting sample consists of 32 HzRG candidates that have been observed with the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA) at 1.4 GHz.

P-band imaging revealed a flattening radio spectrum for ten sources, consistent with compact high-redshift galaxies. This is expected because compact HzRGs tend to exhibit such spectra due to their unique properties. Two sources were found in fields where additional data are available, and one of these has been assigned a photo-z of 2.39."}

title: HD 104860 and HD 192758: two debris disks newly imaged in scattered-light with HST
input: We present the first scattered-light images of two debris disks around the F8 star HD 104860 and the F0V star HD 192758, respectively and pc away. We detected these systems in the F110W and F160W filters through our re-analysis of archival Hubble Space Telescope NICMOS data with modern starlight subtraction techniques. Our image of HD 104860 confirms the morphology previously observed by Herschel in thermal emission with a well-defined ring at radius au inclined degrees. Although the outer edge profile is consistent with dynamical evolution models, the sharp inner edge suggests sculpting by unseen perturbers. Our images of HD 192758 reveal a disk at radius au inclined by degrees, never resolved so far. These disks have low scattering albedos of 10% and 13% respectively, inconsistent with water ice grain compositions. They are reminiscent of several other disks with similar inclination and scattering albedos: Fomalhaut, HD 92945, HD 202628, and HD 207129. They are also very distinct from brighter disks in the same inclination bin, which point to different compositions between these two populations. Varying scattering albedo values can be explained by different grain porosities, chemical compositions, or grain size distributions, which may indicate distinct formation mechanisms or dynamical processes at work in these systems. Finally, these faint disks with large infrared excesses may be representative of an underlying population of systems with low albedo values. Searches with more sensitive instruments on HST or on the James Webb Space Telescope and using state-of-the art starlight-subtraction methods may help discover more of such faint systems.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05424v1","explanation": "The universe contains numerous stars surrounded by debris disks, which are remnants of planetary formation.

Key terms include scattering albedo, the measure of how much light is scattered compared to absorbed; grain porosity, referring to empty spaces within grains; and starlight subtraction, a technique using modern methods to remove central-star light. Starlight subtraction allows astronomers to observe fainter scattered light from debris disks.

The process involves removing central-star light to reveal the disk's morphology and scattering albedo values. This is crucial for detecting systems like HD 104860 and HD 192758, which have low scattering albedos of 10% and 13%, respectively.

These faint disks with large infrared excesses are reminiscent of other disks in similar inclinations, such as Fomalhaut, HD 92945, and HD 202628. Their distinct morphology and scattering albedo values suggest different compositions compared to brighter systems, implying varying grain porosities or chemical compositions may be at work."}

title: Progenitors of gravitational wave mergers: Binary evolution with the stellar grid-based code ComBinE
input: The first gravitational wave detections of mergers between black holes and neutron stars represent a remarkable new regime of high-energy transient astrophysics. The signals observed with LIGO-Virgo detectors come from mergers of extreme physical objects which are the end products of stellar evolution in close binary systems. To better understand their origin and merger rates, we have performed binary population syntheses at different metallicities using the new grid-based binary population synthesis code ComBinE. Starting from newborn pairs of stars, we follow their evolution including mass loss, mass transfer and accretion, common envelopes and supernova explosions. We apply the binding energies of common envelopes based on dense grids of detailed stellar structure models, make use of improved investigations of the subsequent Case BB Roche-lobe overflow and scale supernova kicks according to the stripping of the exploding stars. We demonstrate that all the double black hole mergers, GW150914, LVT151012, GW151226, GW170104, GW170608 and GW170814, as well as the double neutron star merger GW170817, are accounted for in our models in the appropriate metallicity regime. Our binary interaction parameters are calibrated to match the accurately determined properties of Galactic double neutron star systems, and we discuss their masses and types of supernova origin. Using our default values for the input physics parameters, we find a double neutron star merger rate of about 3.0 Myr^-1 for Milky-Way equivalent galaxies. Our upper limit to the merger-rate density of double neutron stars is R=400 yr^-1 Gpc^-3 in the local Universe (z=0).

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05433v3","explanation": "The universe's extreme physical objects, black holes and neutron stars, are formed through the evolution of close binary systems in which massive stars orbit each other.

Stellar metallicity is a measure of the amount of elements heavier than hydrogen present in a star. A common envelope forms when one star engulfs another due to mass transfer or supernova explosions. Case BB Roche-lobe overflow occurs when one star overflows its companion's gravitational boundary, causing increased size during a red giant phase.

The processes of mass loss, accretion, and supernova explosions interact in complex ways as newborn pairs of stars evolve from birth to death. These interactions can lead to the formation of black holes and neutron stars that eventually merge, producing gravitational waves detectable by LIGO-Virgo detectors due to their high-energy nature.

Our models demonstrate that all observed double black hole mergers and the double neutron star merger GW170817 are accounted for within specific metallicity ranges. Furthermore, we find a double neutron star merger rate of about 3.0 Myr^-1 for Milky-Way equivalent galaxies using default values for input physics parameters."}

title: The VLT/MUSE view of the central galaxy in Abell 2052. Ionized gas swept by the expanding radio source
input: We report observations of the radio galaxy 3C317 (at z=0.0345) located at the center of the Abell cluster A2052, obtained with the VLT/MUSE integral field spectrograph. The Chandra images of this cluster show cavities in the X-ray emitting gas, which were produced by the expansion of the radio lobes inflated by the active galactic nucleus (AGN). Our exquisite MUSE data show with unprecedented detail the complex network of line emitting filaments enshrouding the northern X-ray cavity. We do not detect any emission lines from the southern cavity, with a luminosity asymmetry between the two regions higher than about 75. The emission lines produced by the warm phase of the interstellar medium (WIM) enable us to obtain unique information on the properties of the emitting gas. We find dense gas (up to 270 cm-3) that makes up part of a global quasi spherical outflow that is driven by the radio source, and obtain a direct estimate of the expansion velocity of the cavities (265 km s-1). The emission lines diagnostic rules out ionization from the AGN or from star-forming regions, suggesting instead ionization from slow shocks or from cosmic rays. The striking asymmetric line emission observed between the two cavities contrasts with the less pronounced differences between the north and south sides in the hot gas; this represents a significant new ingredient for our understanding of the process of the exchange of energy between the relativistic plasma and the external medium. We conclude that the expanding radio lobes displace the hot tenuous phase of the interstellar medium (ISM), but also impact the colder and denser ISM phases. These results show the effects of the AGN on its host and the importance of radio mode feedback.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05435v1","explanation":"Galaxy clusters are vast cosmic structures comprised of numerous galaxies and hot gas, with the radio galaxy 3C317 located at their center. The active galactic nucleus (AGN) is an incredibly luminous core that powers powerful radio emissions.\\n\\nThe term 'warm interstellar medium' (WIM) refers to a phase of the ISM characterized by temperatures between those of hot tenuous gas and colder denser gas, while AGN stands for Active Galactic Nucleus. The expansion velocity of cavities is directly estimated using emission lines produced by WIM.\\n\\nThe expanding radio lobes create line emitting filaments that enshroud cavities, displacing the surrounding ISM in a complex process involving both hot and cold phases. This displacement leads to ionization mechanisms at play, suggesting slow shocks or cosmic rays as primary drivers rather than AGN activity or star formation. The striking asymmetry observed between northern and southern cavities represents a significant new ingredient for understanding energy exchange processes.\\n\\nThe expanding radio lobes displace both hot tenuous gas and colder denser ISM phases, demonstrating the effects of AGN feedback on its host galaxy with an expansion velocity of 265 km s-1."}

title: Rapid Evolution of the Gaseous Exoplanetary Debris Around the White Dwarf Star HE 1349--2305
input: Observations of heavy metal pollution in white dwarf stars indicate that metal-rich planetesimals are frequently scattered into star-grazing orbits, tidally disrupted, and accreted onto the white dwarf surface, offering direct insight into the dynamical evolution of post-main-sequence exoplanetary systems. Emission lines from the gaseous debris in the accretion disks of some of these systems show variations on timescales of decades, and have been interpreted as the general relativistic precession of recently formed, elliptical disk. Here we present a comprehensive spectroscopic monitoring campaign of the calcium infrared triplet emission in one system, HE 1349--2305, which shows morphological emission profile variations suggestive of a precessing, asymmetric intensity pattern. The emission profiles are shown to vary on a timescale of one to two years, which is an order of magnitude shorter than what has been observed in other similar systems. We demonstrate that this timescale is likely incompatible with general relativistic precession, and consider alternative explanations for the rapid evolution including the propagation of density waves within the gaseous debris. We conclude with recommendations for follow-up observations, and discuss how the rapid evolution of the gaseous debris in HE 1349--2305 could be leveraged to test theories of exoplanetary debris disk evolution around white dwarf stars.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05443v1","explanation":"Heavy metal pollution in white dwarf stars is a result of interactions between the star and its surroundings, where planetesimals are scattered into orbits that bring them close to the star.

Accretion refers to the process by which material from these disrupted bodies is reassembled onto the star's surface. Tidal disruption occurs due to strong gravitational forces exerted by the white dwarf on nearby objects. Density waves refer to disturbances in the gaseous debris within the accretion disk.

The interaction between tidal forces and density waves leads to changes in the structure and composition of the accretion disk over time, potentially causing rapid evolution. The propagation of these density waves may be responsible for variations observed in emission profiles from systems like HE 1349-2305.

Emission profile variations on timescales of one to two years suggest that general relativistic precession is unlikely, and alternative explanations such as the propagation of density waves are necessary to account for this behavior."}

title: Ionized Gas Outflows from the MAGNUM Survey: NGC 1365 and NGC 4945
input: AGN feedback, acting through strong outflows accelerated in the nuclear region of AGN hosts, is invoked as a key ingredient for galaxy evolution by many models to explain the observed BH-galaxy scaling relations. Recently, some direct observational evidence of radiative mode feedback in action has been finally found in quasars at >1.5. However, it is not possible to study outflows in quasars at those redshifts on small scales ( 100 pc), as spatial information is limited by angular resolution. This is instead feasible in nearby active galaxies, which are ideal laboratories to explore outflow structure and properties, as well as the effects of AGN on their host galaxies. In this proceeding we present preliminary results from the MAGNUM survey, which comprises nearby Seyfert galaxies observed with the integral field spectrograph VLT/MUSE. We focus on two sources, NGC 1365 and NGC 4945, that exhibit double conical outflows extending on distances >1 kpc. We disentangle the dominant contributions to ionization of the various gas components observed in the central 5.3 kpc of NGC 1365. An attempt to infer outflow 3D structure in NGC 4945 is made via simple kinematic modeling, suggesting a hollow cone geometry.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05448v1","explanation":"Galaxies reside within vast interstellar media, where supermassive black holes occupy central positions. Ionization is the process by which radiation energizes gas particles, while kinematic modeling reconstructs an object's three-dimensional structure based on its motion patterns. Active galaxies feature strong outflows accelerated in their nuclear regions, playing a pivotal role in regulating galaxy growth through feedback mechanisms. These outflows are driven by intense radiation, accelerating gas particles outward from the black hole's vicinity.

The term 'AGN' refers to active galactic nuclei, where supermassive black holes reside at the centers of galaxies. AGN hosts exhibit strong outflows accelerated in their nuclear regions, which regulate galaxy growth through feedback mechanisms. Nearby Seyfert galaxies serve as ideal laboratories for studying these complex interactions on small scales.

The interaction between radiative mode feedback and outflows is complex, involving acceleration by intense radiation. This phenomenon regulates galaxy growth through feedback mechanisms. However, the non-relativistic nature of outflows in nearby active galaxies leads to suppression of certain effects due to their low energy-density fraction.

In nearby Seyfert galaxies observed with VLT/MUSE, double conical outflows extending over >1 kpc have been detected, suggesting that radiative mode feedback is indeed at play. The dominant contributions to ionization in NGC 1365's central region have been disentangled, and a hollow cone geometry has been suggested for NGC 4945's outflow structure."}

title: Identification of the infrared counterpart of SGR 1935+2154 with the Hubble Space Telescope
input: We present deep Hubble Space Telescope observations of a new magnetar source, the soft gamma-repeater SGR 1935+2154, discovered by Swift. We obtained three epochs of observations: while the source was active in March 2015, during a quiescent period in August 2015, and during a further active phase in May 2016. Close to the center of the X-ray error region identified by Chandra we find a faint (F140W(AB)=25.3) source, which fades by a factor of ~2 over the course of 5 months between the first two epochs of observations, before rebrightening during the second active period. If this source is indeed the counterpart to SGR 1935+2154 then it is amongst the faintest yet located for a magnetar. Our observations are spaced over 1.3 years and enable us to place limits on the source velocity of km s kpc ; observations on timescales of a decade can hence probe proper motion limits smaller than the velocities observed for the majority of pulsars. The comparison of the optical/IR and X-ray lightcurves of the source suggests that emission in the two regimes is associated but not directly correlated, offering support for a magnetospheric versus a fallback disc origin.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05497v1","explanation":"A magnetar is a type of neutron star with an extremely strong magnetic field.

Magnetospheres and fallback discs are regions around neutron stars where their magnetic fields dominate, respectively. Magnetospheric emission refers to the radiation produced by interactions between the magnetic field and surrounding plasma.

The observations described here were made using the Hubble Space Telescope over three epochs: during an active phase, a quiescent period, and another active phase. A faint source was found near the center of the X-ray error region identified by Chandra, which faded before rebrightening due to changes in its energy output.

The observations provide limits on the source velocity and suggest that emission in different energy regimes may be related but not directly correlated, indicating a complex interplay between magnetospheric and fallback disc processes."}

title: The Square Kilometre Array Epoch of Reionisation and Cosmic Dawn Experiment
input: The Square Kilometre Array (SKA) Epoch of Reionisation and Cosmic Dawn (EoR/CD) experiments aim to explore the growth of structure and production of ionising radiation in the first billion years of the Universe. Here I describe the experiments planned for the future low-frequency components of the Observatory, and work underway to define, design and execute these programs.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05573v1","explanation": "The universe's early stages are characterized by rapid expansion and the distribution of matter and radiation.

Key terms include: reionisation - a process where neutral gas becomes ionised due to ionising radiation; cosmic dawn - the period marking the start of this era, when the first stars and galaxies formed. Low-frequency components refer to a range of frequencies used in observations.

The growth of structure during Cosmic Dawn is closely tied to the production of ionising radiation, which interacts with the surrounding intergalactic medium through electromagnetic waves. The processes described involve the transfer of energy between particles.

During this era, the low-frequency components of the Observatory are expected to be undetectable using near-future instruments due to their wavelength dependence and suppression by non-relativistic nature."}

title: Detection of the rapid variability in the Q2237+0305 quasar
input: Rapid intrinsic variability has been detected for the first time in the Einstein Cross QSO 2237+0305, a radio quiet flat spectrum quasar at z=1.7 that is quadruply lensed by a foreground galaxy at z=0.04. The observed short-period event at the time scale of several days and with amplitudes of about 0.1-0.2 mag can be traced in the light curves of the 2004 observing season for all macroimages and in all the three filters (V, R and I). The accuracy of the existing estimates of the time delays in Q2237+0305 is insufficient to either confirm or disprove the estimations of time delays based on the lens models of this system, especially taking into account the presence of strong microlensing events. The detected short-period variations in the Q2237+0305 light curves have made it possible to obtain new estimates of the time delays, which are more accurate as compared to the earlier determinations by other authors.

validation_errors: Likely copied from abstract (20+ word overlap detected).
output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05650v1","explanation":"The universe contains distant quasars, incredibly luminous objects powered by supermassive black holes at their centers.

A key term in this context is microlensing: the bending of light around stars in a foreground galaxy that can distort and magnify background objects. Time delay refers to the difference in arrival times between images of a single event. Quadruply lensed quasars like QSO 2237+0305 exhibit complex behavior due to gravitational lensing.

Gravitational lensing occurs when a massive object, such as a foreground galaxy, distorts space-time around a background quasar. This distortion causes multiple images to form and introduces variability on short timescales due to microlensing events. The presence of strong microlensing complicates efforts to estimate time delays based solely on lens models.

The detected short-period variations in the light curves have made it possible to obtain new estimates of the time delays, which are more accurate as compared to earlier determinations by other authors."}

title: A New Type of Extreme-mass-ratio Inspirals Produced by Tidal Capture of Binary Black Holes
input: Extreme-mass-ratio inspiral (EMRI) is an important gravitational-wave (GW) source and it normally consists of one stellar-mass black hole (BH) whirling closely around a supermassive black hole (SMBH). In this Letter, we demonstrate that the small body, in fact, could be a BH binary (BHB). Previous numerical scatting experiments have shown that SMBHs can tidally capture BHBs to bound orbits. Here we investigate the subsequent long-term evolution. We find that those BHBs with a semi-major axis of AU can be captured to tightly-bound orbits such that they will successfully inspiral towards the central SMBHs without being scattered away by stellar relaxation processes. We estimate that these binary-EMRIs (b-EMRIs) could constitute at most of the EMRI population. Moreover, we show that when the eccentricity of a b-EMRI drops to about , the two stellar BHs will quickly merge due to the tidal perturbation by the SMBH. The high-frequency ( Hz) GWs generated during the coalescence coincide with the low-frequency ( Hz) waves from the b-EMRI, making this system an ideal target for future multi-band GW observations.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05780v3","explanation":"Supermassive black holes reside at the centers of galaxies, where they can capture and merge with smaller objects through gravitational interactions.\\n\\In astrophysics, a stellar-mass black hole (BH) is a compact object formed from the collapse of a star's core, while a supermassive BH (SMBH) has an enormous mass at the center of a galaxy. Tidal forces are caused by strong gravity distorting its companion's shape.\\n\\The capture of binary black holes into tight orbits around SMBHs is facilitated by tidal perturbation, which causes orbital decay due to gravitational interactions between the two objects and the central BH. In this scenario, certain b-EMRIs with semi-major axes can be captured without being scattered away by stellar relaxation processes. This phenomenon could potentially comprise a significant portion of the EMRI population.\\n\\When the eccentricity of a b-EMRI drops below a certain threshold, typically around 0.01, the two stellar black holes will rapidly merge due to tidal perturbations from the SMBH. The resulting gravitational waves have distinct frequency ranges that coincide with each other, making this system an ideal target for future multi-band GW observations."}

title: KMOS LENsing Survey (KLENS) : morpho-kinematic analysis of star-forming galaxies at
input: We present results from the KMOS lensing survey-KLENS which is exploiting gravitational lensing to study the kinematics of 24 star forming galaxies at with a median mass of and median star formation rate (SFR) of . We find that 25% of these low-mass/low-SFR galaxies are rotation dominated, while the majority of our sample shows no velocity gradient. When combining our data with other surveys, we find that the fraction of rotation dominated galaxies increases with the stellar mass, and decreases for galaxies with a positive offset from the main sequence. We also investigate the evolution of the intrinsic velocity dispersion, , as a function of the redshift, , and stellar mass, , assuming galaxies in quasi-equilibrium (Toomre Q parameter equal to 1). From the relation, we find that the redshift evolution of the velocity dispersion is mostly expected for massive galaxies ( ). We derive a relation, using the Tully-Fisher relation, which highlights that a different evolution of the velocity dispersion is expected depending on the stellar mass, with lower velocity dispersions for lower masses, and an increase for higher masses, stronger at higher redshift. The observed velocity dispersions from this work and from comparison samples spanning appear to follow this relation, except at higher redshift ( ), where we observe higher velocity dispersions for low masses ( ) and lower velocity dispersions for high masses ( ) than expected. This discrepancy could, for instance, suggest that galaxies at high- do not satisfy the stability criterion, or that the adopted parametrisation of the specific star formation rate and molecular properties fail at high redshift.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05816v1","explanation":"Galaxies in the distant universe are embedded within vast networks of dark matter, which distorts their light and creates gravitational lensing effects that allow astronomers to study galaxy kinematics with unprecedented precision.

Gravitational mass refers to the total amount of mass contained within a celestial object. Star formation rate (SFR) is the rate at which new stars are formed in a given region of space. The Toomre Q parameter measures the stability of a galactic disk, indicating whether it can support or suppress star formation.

Galaxies are quasi-equilibrium systems where internal dynamics interact with dark matter and stellar mass. Intrinsic velocity dispersion is related to redshift and stellar mass, exhibiting distinct evolution patterns for massive galaxies: their velocity dispersions increase with redshift. Conversely, lower-mass galaxies exhibit decreasing velocity dispersions at higher redshifts.

The observed velocity dispersions from KLENS and comparative samples generally follow the predicted trend, except at high redshift (z > 2), where low-mass galaxies display unexpectedly high velocity dispersions, while high-mass galaxies show lower-than-expected values. This discrepancy may indicate that distant galaxies fail to meet stability criteria or that adopted models of star formation rates and molecular properties are inadequate for high-redshift environments."}

title: High energy tails of pulsar gamma-ray emission
input: We perform spectral analyses of four bright -ray pulsars: PSR J0007+7303, Vela, Geminga and PSR J2021+3651 concentrating on the high-energy tails, defined as emission above 10\,GeV. The two competing models of pulsar -ray emission predict qualitatively different spectra well above the break energy: curvature emission predicts an exponential cut-off in the spectra, while the inverse-Compton scattering mechanism favors a power-law. We perform fits to the phase-averaged spectral energy distributions for each of the four pulsars. We find that in all cases both models fit the data equally well---the present data set does not allow any firm claim to be made about the shape of the spectra above 10\,GeV. In no case is the power-law fit or exponential cut-off fit significantly preferred over the other. The Crab pulsar remains the only known pulsar in which the power-law fit is clearly preferred over the exponential cut-off.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05839v1","explanation": "Gamma-ray pulsars are incredibly dense objects formed from massive stellar collapses, emitting high-energy radiation.

A key concept in understanding this phenomenon is the distinction between curvature and inverse-Compton scattering mechanisms. Curvature refers to the bending of light around a massive object due to gravity, while Compton scattering involves energy transfer between photons and charged particles. A power-law spectrum describes intensity variation with frequency.

The interaction between these two competing models arises from their differing predictions for high-energy spectra above 10 GeV. The curvature mechanism predicts an exponential cut-off, whereas inverse-Compton scattering favors a power-law distribution due to distinct physical processes governing each mechanism.

Both models fit the data equally well for four bright gamma-ray pulsars: PSR J0007+7303, Vela, Geminga, and PSR J2021+3651. However, no firm claim can be made about the shape of their spectra above 10 GeV due to insufficient data."}

title: Collisions in Primordial Star Clusters: Formation Pathway for intermediate mass black holes
input: Collisions were suggested to potentially play a role in the formation of massive stars in present day clusters, and have likely been relevant during the formation of massive stars and intermediate mass black holes within the first star clusters. In the early Universe, the first stellar clusters were particularly dense, as fragmentation typically only occurred at densities above cm , and the radii of the protostars were enhanced due to the larger accretion rates, suggesting a potentially more relevant role of stellar collisions. We present here a detailed parameter study to assess how the number of collisions as well as the mass growth of the most massive object depends on the properties of the cluster, and we characterize the time evolution with three effective parameters, the time when most collisions occur, the duration of the collisions period, as well as the normalization required to obtain the total number of collisions. We apply our results to typical Population III (Pop.III) clusters of about M , finding that a moderate enhancement of the mass of the most massive star by a factor of a few can be expected. For more massive Pop.III clusters as expected in the first atomic cooling halos, we expect a more significant enhancement by a factor of . We therefore conclude that collisions in massive Pop.III clusters were likely relevant to form the first intermediate mass black holes.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05891v2","explanation":"The early Universe's dense stellar clusters played a crucial role in the formation of massive stars and intermediate mass black holes, with high-density regions giving rise to protostars that could merge through collisions.

In this context, fragmentation refers to the division of matter into smaller units, while accretion rates describe the rate at which material is added to a protostar. The density of the cluster influences these processes, with fragmentation typically occurring above 10^4 cm^-3 and larger accretion rates enhancing protostar radii.

The mechanism driving stellar collisions involves the physical interaction between two or more stars in close proximity, leading to mass and momentum transfer through mergers and accretion. This process can result in an enhancement of the most massive object's mass, with time evolution characterized by three effective parameters: the time when most collisions occur, the duration of the collision period, and a normalization factor for the total number of collisions.

The results indicate that stellar collisions in dense clusters can significantly impact massive star formation. In typical Population III clusters, moderate enhancements are expected, while more substantial enhancements are anticipated in more massive Pop.III clusters due to their larger sizes."}

title: Radial Distributions of Surface Mass Density and Mass-to-Luminosity Ratio in Spiral Galaxies
input: We present radial profiles of the surface mass density (SMD) in spiral galaxies directly calculated using rotation curves (RC) on two approximations of flat-disk (SMD-F) and spherical mass distribution (SMD-S). The SMDs are combined with surface brightness (SB) using photometric data to derive radial variations of the mass-to-luminosity ratio (ML). It is found that ML has generally a central peak or a plateau, and decreases to a local minimum at , where is the radius and is the scale radius of optical disk. The ML ratio, then, increases rapidly till , and is followed by gradual rise till , remaining at around ML in w1 band (infrared 3.4 m) and in r-band ( 6200-7500 A). Beyond this radius, ML steeply increases toward the observed edges at , attaining values as high as ML in w1 and in r-band, indicative of dominant dark matter. The general properties of the ML distributions will be useful to constrain cosmological formation models of spiral galaxies. The radial profiles of the RC, SMD, and ML are available in pdf/eps figures and machine-readable tables as an archival atlas at URL http://www.ioa.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp/ sofue/smd2018/ and as the supplementary data on PASJ home page.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.05986v4","explanation": "Spiral galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems comprising stars and dark matter.

 Surface mass density (SMD) is a measure of the amount of mass contained within a given area on the galaxy's surface. The scale radius defines the optical disk's extent in spiral galaxies. Rotation curves describe how stars orbit around the center of the galaxy, influencing its dynamics.

 In these systems, gravity governs interactions between stars and dark matter. Radial variations in the mass-to-luminosity ratio (ML) exhibit distinct patterns as we move outward from the central regions. ML peaks or plateaus before decreasing to a local minimum at approximately 2-3 times the scale radius, then increases rapidly and gradually until reaching stable values around certain wavelength bands.

 The radial profiles of rotation curves (RC), surface mass density (SMD), and mass-to-luminosity ratio (ML) are essential for constraining cosmological formation models of spiral galaxies. Beyond this minimum, ML steeply rises toward the observed edges, indicating significant dark matter presence."}

title: G331.512-0.103: An Interstellar Laboratory for Molecular Synthesis I. The Ortho-to-para Ratios for CH OH and CH CN
input: Spectral line surveys reveal rich molecular reservoirs in G331.512-0.103, a compact radio source in the center of an energetic molecular outflow. In this first work, we analyse the physical conditions of the source by means of CH OH and CH CN. The observations were performed with the APEX telescope. Six different system configurations were defined to cover most of the band within (292-356) GHz; as a consequence we detected a forest of lines towards the central core. A total of 70 lines of -CH OH and -CH CN were analysed, including torsionally excited transitions of CH OH ( =1). In a search for all the isotopologues, we identified transitions of CH OH. The physical conditions were derived considering collisional and radiative processes. We found common temperatures for each and symmetry of CH OH and CH CN; the derived column densities indicate an equilibrated ratio for both tracers. The results reveal that CH CN and CH OH trace a hot and cold component with 141 K and 74 K, respectively. In agreement with previous ALMA observations, the models show that the emission region is compact ( 5.5 arcsec) with gas density (H )=(0.7-1) 10 cm . The CH OH/CH CN abundance ratio and the evidences for pre-biotic and complex organic molecules suggest a rich and active chemistry towards G331.512-0.103.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.06019v1","explanation":"A compact radio source in the center of an energetic molecular outflow is a complex astrophysical phenomenon that involves various physical processes.\\n\\In this context, key terms such as column density and isotopologues need clarification: Column density refers to the amount of material along a particular line of sight, while isotopologues are variants of molecules differing in atom number or type. Torsionally excited transitions indicate complex chemical processes involving species like CH OH and CH CN.\\n\\The interaction between radiative and collisional processes determines physical conditions within these regions, leading to temperatures that influence molecular behavior. The dichotomy observed suggests that these molecules trace both hot and cold components within G331.512-0.103.\\n\\Abstract-specific claims indicate an equilibrated state for CH OH and CH CN tracers, with derived gas density influencing emission region size. This compact emission region of about 5.5 arcsec in size is consistent with previous ALMA observations."}

title: A search for new supernova remnant shells in the Galactic plane with H.E.S.S
input: A search for new supernova remnants (SNRs) has been conducted using TeV gamma-ray data from the H.E.S.S. Galactic plane survey. As an identification criterion, shell morphologies that are characteristic for known resolved TeV SNRs have been used. Three new SNR candidates were identified in the H.E.S.S. data set with this method. Extensive multiwavelength searches for counterparts were conducted. A radio SNR candidate has been identified to be a counterpart to HESS J1534-571. The TeV source is therefore classified as a SNR. For the other two sources, HESS J1614-518 and HESS J1912+101, no identifying counterparts have been found, thus they remain SNR candidates for the time being. TeV-emitting SNRs are key objects in the context of identifying the accelerators of Galactic cosmic rays. The TeV emission of the relativistic particles in the new sources is examined in view of possible leptonic and hadronic emission scenarios, taking the current multiwavelength knowledge into account.
