{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08659v2","explanation":"Binary systems with intermediate masses are characterized by their long photometric periods, which can last 33 times the orbital period.

A semi-detached eclipsing binary is a specific configuration where one star has expanded to fill its Roche lobe, allowing mass transfer onto the companion. The term 'semi-detached' refers to this particular arrangement of stars in close orbit around each other. Additionally, a disc can be thought of as a geometrically thick structure surrounding a hot dwarf.

The interaction between the cool evolved star and the hot companion leads to the formation of a concave and geometrically thick disc that contributes significantly to the total luminosity at the V band. The mass transfer stream impacts the external edge of this disc, forming a hotspot region hotter than its surroundings.

The binary system's behavior is influenced by its inclination and distance from Earth. A cool evolved star with temperatures around 4000 Kelvin and a hot companion with temperatures around 20000 Kelvin are present in the system. The light curve analysis suggests that the presence of a wind in the hotspot region is possible due to the detection of a secondary absorption component in He I lines and the persistent asymmetry of H emission."}

title: Lurking systematics in predicting galaxy cold gas masses using dust luminosities and star formation rates
input: We use galaxies from the Herschel Reference Survey to evaluate commonly used indirect predictors of cold gas masses. We calibrate predictions for cold neutral atomic and molecular gas using infrared dust emission and gas depletion time methods which are self-consistent and have ~20% accuracy (with the highest accuracy in the prediction of total cold gas mass). However, modest systematic residual dependences are found in all calibrations which depend on the partition between molecular and atomic gas, and can over/under-predict gas masses by up to 0.3dex. As expected, dust-based estimates are best at predicting the total gas mass while depletion time-based estimates are only able to predict the (star-forming) molecular gas mass. Additionally, we advise caution when applying these predictions to high-z galaxies, as significant (0.5dex or more) errors can arise when incorrect assumptions are made about the dominant gas phase. Any scaling relations derived using predicted gas masses may be more closely related to the calibrations used than to the actual galaxies observed.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08687v1","explanation":"Galaxies are vast, gravitationally bound systems consisting of stars, gas, and dust.\n\nIn this context, key terms such as "		}

title: Stellar metallicity variations across spiral arms in disk galaxies with multiple populations
input: This letter studies the formation of azimuthal metallicity variations in the disks of spiral galaxies in the absence of initial radial metallicity gradients. Using high-resolution -body simulations, we model composite stellar discs, made of kinematically cold and hot stellar populations, and study their response to spiral arm perturbations. We find that, as expected, disk populations with different kinematics respond differently to a spiral perturbation, with the tendency for dynamically cooler populations to show a larger fractional contribution to spiral arms than dynamically hotter populations. By assuming a relation between kinematics and metallicity, namely the hotter the population, the more metal-poor it is, this differential response to the spiral arm perturbations naturally leads to azimuthal variations in the mean metallicity of stars in the simulated disk. Thus, azimuthal variations in the mean metallicity of stars across a spiral galaxy are not necessarily a consequence of the reshaping, by radial migration, of an initial radial metallicity gradient. They indeed arise naturally also in stellar disks which have initially only a negative vertical metallicity gradient.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08711v1","explanation": "Spiral galaxies are vast, flat disks of stars and gas that rotate around a central bulge.

Metallicity refers to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen in stellar populations. Kinematically cold populations have slower rotations, while kinematically hot populations are faster rotators.

When spiral arm perturbations occur, different types of stellar populations respond differently due to their distinct rotation velocities and assumed relationship with metal content. This differential response leads to variations in mean metallicity across the galaxy disk.

The simulations show that azimuthal metallicity variations can arise naturally without an initial radial metallicity gradient, as dynamically cooler populations tend to contribute more to spiral arms than hotter ones."}

title: The Near-Infrared Outflow and Cavity of the proto-Brown Dwarf Candidate ISO-Oph 200
input: In this letter a near-infrared integral field study of a proto-brown dwarf candidate is presented. A 0 5 blue-shifted outflow is detected in both H and [Fe II] lines at V = (-35~ 2)~km~s and V = (-51~ 5)~km~s respectively. In addition, slower ( ~10~km~s ) H emission is detected out to 5 4, in the direction of both the blue and red-shifted outflow lobes but along a different position angle to the more compact faster emission. It is argued that the more compact emission is a jet and the extended H emission is tracing a cavity. The source extinction is estimated at A = 18 mag 1 mag and the outflow extinction at Av = 9 mag 0.4 mag. The H outflow temperature is calculated to be 1422 K ~255~K and the electron density of the [Fe II] outflow is measured at 10000 cm . Furthermore, the mass outflow rate is estimated at = 3.8 10 ~ ~yr and = 1 10 ~ ~yr . takes a Fe depletion of 88 into account. The depletion is investigated using the ratio of the [FeII]~1.257~ m and [PII]~1.188~ m lines. Using the Pa and Br lines and a range in stellar mass and radius is calculated to be (3 - 10) 10 ~ ~yr . Comparing these rates puts the jet efficiency in line with predictions of magneto-centrifugal models of jet launching in low mass protostars. This is a further case of a brown dwarf outflow exhibiting analogous properties to protostellar jets.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08749v1","explanation":"The proto-brown dwarf candidate is situated in a region where star formation occurs, with gas and dust collapsing under gravity to form new stars.\\n\\nThe term 'proto-brown dwarf' refers to an object that has not yet reached brown dwarf status due to its low mass; it's also known as a very-low-mass protostar. Blue-shifted outflows signify high-velocity material ejection, likely driven by magnetic fields or other processes. The detection of [Fe II] lines indicates the presence of iron ions in the gas at specific wavelengths.\\n\\nThe temperature and electron density of the outflow are approximately 1422 K and 10000 cm^-3 respectively; these values suggest a hot, dense region of gas being expelled from the system. Extinction refers to light blocking or absorption by intervening material in space. The mass outflow rate is estimated between 3.8 x 10^-9 and 1 x 10^-7 solar masses per year, considering Fe depletion factors.\\n\\nThe slower H emission tracing a cavity implies that the more compact faster emission is indeed a jet; this system's properties are analogous to those found in protostellar jets, supporting magneto-centrifugal models of jet launching."}

title: Suppressed phase variations in a high amplitude rapidly oscillating Ap star pulsating in a distorted quadrupole mode
input: We present the results of a multisite photometric observing campaign on the rapidly oscillating Ap (roAp) star 2MASS 16400299-0737293 (J1640; ). We analyse photometric data to show the star pulsates at a frequency of d ( Hz; min) with a peak-to-peak amplitude of 20.68 mmag, making it one of the highest amplitude roAp stars. No further pulsation modes are detected. The stellar rotation period is measured at d, and we show that rotational modulation due to spots is in anti-phase between broadband and observations. Analysis and modelling of the pulsation reveals this star to be pulsating in a distorted quadrupole mode, but with a strong spherically symmetric component. The pulsational phase variation in this star is suppressed, leading to the conclusion that the contribution of components dictate the shape of phase variations in roAp stars that pulsate in quadrupole modes. This is only the fourth time such a strong pulsation phase suppression has been observed, leading us to question the mechanisms at work in these stars. We classify J1640 as an A7 Vp SrEu(Cr) star through analysis of classification resolution spectra.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08837v1","explanation":"Rapidly oscillating Ap stars like J1640 are found in the upper part of the main sequence, where they exhibit complex interactions between pulsations and rotation. \\n\\nThe term roAp star refers to a specific type of star characterized by strong magnetic fields and surface chemical peculiarities such as an overabundance of strontium and europium. A distorted quadrupole mode is a particular type of pulsation where the star's atmosphere expands and contracts in a non-symmetric manner, while rotational modulation due to spots on the stellar surface plays a crucial role in this phenomenon. \\n\\nThe mechanism at play involves the interplay between these two processes: rotational modulation caused by spots and the distorted quadrupole mode itself. The analysis reveals that the strong spherically symmetric component of this mode suppresses the pulsational phase variation, leading to a unique phenomenon where the contribution of components dictates the shape of phase variations in roAp stars that pulsate in quadrupole modes. This suppression is particularly notable as it has only been observed four times before, and its implications for understanding these complex systems are significant."}

title: Searching for Primordial Magnetic Fields with CMB B-modes
input: Was the primordial universe magnetized? The answer to this question would help explain the origin of micro-Gauss strength magnetic fields observed in galaxies. It is also of fundamental importance in developing a complete theory of the early universe. While there can be other signatures of cosmological magnetic fields, a signature in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) would prove their primordial origin. The B-mode polarization of CMB is particularly promising in this regard because there are relatively few other sources of B-modes, and because the vortical modes sourced by the primordial magnetic field (PMF) survive diffusion damping up to a small fraction of the Silk length. At present, the Planck temperature and polarization spectra combined with the B-mode spectrum measured by the South Pole Telescope (SPT) constrain the PMF strength to be no more than nano-Gauss (nG). Because of the quartic scaling of the CMB anisotropy spectra with the PMF strength, this bound will not change by much even with the significantly better measurements of the B-mode spectrum by the Stage III and Stage IV CMB experiments. On the other hand, tightening the bound well below the nG threshold would rule out the purely primordial origin (requiring no dynamo action) of galactic fields. Considering Faraday rotation, which converts some of the E-modes into B-modes and scales linearly with the field strength, will help to achieve this goal. As we demonstrate, the upcoming experiments, such as SPT-3G and the Simons Observatory, will be sensitive to fields of nG strength thanks to the mode-coupling signature induced by Faraday rotation. A future Stage IV ground based experiment or a Space Probe will be capable of probing fields below nG, and would detect a scale-invariant PMF of nG strength without de-lensing or subtracting the galactic rotation measure.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08936v2","explanation":"The universe's early stages involve the formation of galaxies and magnetic fields, which are crucial for understanding these phenomena.

Magnetic field strength is measured in units such as nano-Gauss (nG), while Faraday rotation converts E-modes into B-modes scaling linearly with field strength. Additionally, diffusion damping suppresses certain modes in the cosmic microwave background (CMB).

Primordial magnetic fields interact with the CMB through mode-coupling signatures induced by Faraday rotation, making upcoming experiments sensitive to nG field strengths.

The current bounds on primordial magnetic field strengths are constrained by combining Planck temperature and polarization spectra with the B-mode spectrum measured by the South Pole Telescope (SPT). Tightening this bound below nG would rule out a purely primordial origin of galactic fields, while future experiments may detect scale-invariant PMFs without de-lensing or subtracting galactic rotation measures.

The quartic scaling of CMB anisotropy spectra with the PMF strength means that improved measurements will not significantly change the current bound."}

title: Common Occurrence of Explosive Hydrogen Burning in Type II Supernovae
input: We report Mo isotopic data for 16 15N-rich presolar SiC grains of type AB (14N/15N<solar, AB1) and their correlated Sr and Ba isotope ratios when available. Eight of the 16 AB1 grains show s-process Mo isotopic compositions, together with s-process Ba and/or Sr isotopic compositions. We found that a higher percentage of AB1 grains show anomalous isotopic compositions than that of AB2 grains (14N/15N>solar), thus providing further support to the division of the two AB subgroups recently proposed by Liu et al. (2017a), who showed that AB1 grains most likely originated from Type II supernovae (SNe) with explosive H burning. Comparison of the Sr, Mo, and Ba isotopic compositions of the AB1 grains with SN model predictions indicates that the s-process isotopic compositions of AB1 grains resulted from neutron-capture processes occurring during the progenitor massive stars' pre-SN evolution rather than from an explosive neutron-capture process. In addition, the observations of (1) explosive H burning occurring in the C-rich regions of the progenitor SNe of SN X grains as suggested by the isotopic compositions of X grains, and (2) explosive H burning occurring both at the bottom of the He/C zone and at the top of the He/N zone as suggested by model simulations, imply that explosive H burning is a common phenomenon in outer SN zones.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08954v1","explanation":"The universe's early formation is characterized by the creation of presolar grains, which are remnants from ancient stars that have undergone nuclear reactions in their cores. These grains can be classified into subgroups based on their nitrogen isotopic ratios, with AB1 and AB2 being two distinct categories defined by 14N/15N ratios below or above solar values.\\n\\nThe s-process refers to the formation of heavy elements through neutron capture processes within stars, while Mo isotopes serve as tracers for these processes due to their ability to provide information about the conditions under which they occurred. The term Type II supernovae (SNe) describes a type of massive star explosion that occurs when a star runs out of fuel and collapses in on itself.\\n\\nThe interplay between neutron capture, hydrogen burning, and other physical mechanisms plays a crucial role in the final stages of massive star formation. Specifically, observations suggest that explosive H burning is a common phenomenon in outer SN zones, where it occurs both at the bottom of helium-rich regions and near nitrogen-enriched layers. This highlights the importance of understanding these processes to better comprehend the origins of presolar grains.\\n\\nThe s-process isotopic compositions observed in AB1 grains are consistent with neutron-capture processes occurring during pre-SN evolution rather than an explosive process, indicating that these grains originated from Type II supernovae with explosive H burning."}

title: The ionizing source of the bipolar HII region S106: a close massive binary
input: S106 is one of the best known bipolar HII regions, thoroughly studied and modelled at infrared, submillimeter and millimeter wavelengths, and it is one of the nearest examples of the late stages of massive star formation in which the newly formed star that ionizes it is still surrounded by vast amounts of gas and dust. However, little is known about its heavily obscured central source, S106IR. The possible binarity of the central source is investigated, which is considered to be likely given the high binarity fraction among massive stars. We have carried out visible and near-infrared photometric monitoring looking for short-term variability, with special interest in that related to the presence of a close binary companion to S106IR that may produce periodic eclipses or tidal distortion of the shape of the members of the system. A periodic variability of S106IR in the J band is found with a period of 5.0 days and an amplitude of about 0.1 mag. The light curve displays a slow rise from minimum to maximum followed by a steep decrease, and can be well reproduced by a close binary system composed of two stars with different luminosity orbiting each other in an elliptical orbit of moderate eccentricity. S106IR also shows hints of short-term variability possibly related to accretion. We also report variability of four other stars previously classified as members of the S106 cluster, all of which are strong X-ray emitters. The newly discovered close binarity of S106IR adds a new element to the modeling of the nebula and to the understanding of the dynamics of the gas around the ionizing source, which suggests that the components of the binary are accreting via a circumbinary disk. Binarity also helps to explain the apparent mismatch between the spectral type of the ionizing source inferred from the nebular spectrum and its high brightness at near-infrared wavelengths.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.08958v1","explanation":"Massive star formation involves the collapse of giant molecular clouds into bipolar HII regions, such as S106.

Key terms include binarity - two stars orbiting each other - and accretion - material transferred onto a star or object. Additionally, an elliptical orbit refers to an oval-shaped path around a central point.

The interaction between the components of S106IR in its elliptical orbit with moderate eccentricity leads to periodic variability with a 5-day period and amplitude of about 0.1 mag. This behavior is consistent with expectations from close binary systems, where one star eclipses or distorts the other.

S106IR's close binarity suggests that its components are accreting via a circumbinary disk, which helps explain discrepancies between spectral types inferred from the nebular spectrum and near-infrared brightness."}

title: AAS WorldWide Telescope: Seamless, Cross-Platform Data Visualization Engine for Astronomy Research, Education, and Democratizing Data
input: The American Astronomical Society's WorldWide Telescope (WWT) project enables terabytes of astronomical images, data, and stories to be viewed and shared among researchers, exhibited in science museums, projected into full-dome immersive planetariums and virtual reality headsets, and taught in classrooms from middle school to college levels. We review the WWT ecosystem, how WWT has been used in the astronomical community, and comment on future directions.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09119v1","explanation": "The universe is explored through vast collections of astronomical images and data, which are shared among researchers and exhibited in various settings such as science museums, planetariums, and virtual reality headsets.\\n\\nThe term 'terabytes' refers to extremely large amounts of digital data, often used for storing complex information like images and stories. A full-dome immersive planetarium is a specialized theater that provides an immersive experience for viewers by projecting visuals onto the entire dome-shaped screen. In this context, terabytes of astronomical content are made accessible through a shared platform, enabling researchers to view and share these resources in various settings.\\n\\nThe WorldWide Telescope project facilitates access to vast digital archives, allowing users to explore and engage with complex astrophysical information in immersive environments."}

title: Dissipative dark matter halos: The steady state solution II
input: Within the mirror dark matter model and dissipative dark matter models in general, halos around galaxies with active star formation (including spirals and gas rich dwarfs) are dynamical: they expand and contract in response to heating and cooling processes. Ordinary Type II supernovae (SN) can provide the dominant heat source, possible if kinetic mixing interaction exists with strength . Dissipative dark matter halos can be modelled as a fluid governed by Euler's equations. Around sufficiently isolated and unperturbed galaxies the halo can relax to a steady state configuration, where heating and cooling rates locally balance and hydrostatic equilibrium prevails. These steady state conditions can be solved to derive the physical properties, including the halo density and temperature profiles, for model galaxies. Here, we have considered idealized spherically symmetric galaxies within the mirror dark particle model, as in the earlier paper [paper I, arXiv:1707.02528], but we have assumed that the local halo heating in the SN vicinity dominates over radiative sources. With this assumption, physically interesting steady state solutions arise which we compute for a representative range of model galaxies. The end result is a rather simple description of the dark matter halo around idealized spherically symmetric systems, characterized in principle by only one parameter, with physical properties that closely resemble the empirical properties of disk galaxies.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09359v3","explanation": "Galaxies with active star formation reside in vast, diffuse regions of space known as dark matter halos.

Dissipative refers to a type of dark matter that can be modeled using fluid dynamics equations, such as those derived from Euler's laws. This approach allows for the calculation of physical properties like density and temperature profiles under specific conditions.

In these systems, ordinary supernovae play a crucial role in heating up surrounding dark matter through interactions with kinetic energy. The local halo heating near supernova events dominates over other heat sources, leading to interesting solutions for idealized galaxies.

The resulting steady-state configurations are characterized by a single parameter and exhibit properties that closely resemble those of disk galaxies, where the balance between heating and cooling rates leads to hydrostatic equilibrium."}

title: Fermi-LAT Observation of Non-Blazar AGNs
input: We report on a detailed investigation of the -ray emission from 26 non-blazar AGNs based on the Fermi LAT data accumulated for 7 years. The photon index of non-blazar AGNs changes in the range of 1.84-2.86 and the flux varies from a few times to . Over long time periods, power-law provides an adequate description of the -ray spectra of almost all sources. Significant curvature is observed in the -ray spectra of NGC 1275, NGC 6251, SBS 0846+513 and PMN J0948+0022 and their spectra are better described by log-parabola or power-law with exponential cut-off models. The -ray spectra of PKS 0625-25 and 3C 380 show a possible deviation from a simple power-law shape, indicating a spectral cutoff around the observed photon energy of GeV and GeV, respectively. Our analysis confirms the previous finding of an unusual spectral turnover in the -ray spectrum of Cen A: the photon index changes from to at GeV. In the plane, the luminosity of non-blazar AGNs is spread in the range of , where the lowest luminosity have FRI radio galaxies (but typically appear with a harder photon index) and the highest- SSRQs/NLSY1s (with softer photon indexes). We confirm the previously reported short-timescale flux variability of NGC 1275 and 3C 120. The -ray emission from NLSY1s, 1H 0323+342, SBS 0846+513 and PMN J0948+0022, is variable, showing flares in short scales sometimes accompanied by a moderate hardening of their spectra (e.g., on MJD 56146.8 the -ray photon index of SBS 0846+513 was ). 3C 111, Cen A core, 3C 207, 3C 275.1, 3C 380, 4C+39.23B, PKS 1502+036 and PKS 2004-447 show a long-timescale flux variability in the -ray band.

{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09381v1","explanation":"Gamma-ray emission is a phenomenon observed in distant galaxies, specifically non-blazar Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs). These objects are incredibly luminous and can be described by power-law models over long time periods.

Key terms include: log-parabola and power-law with exponential cut-off models. Log-parabola refers to a mathematical function that describes curved spectra, while power-law with exponential cut-off model accounts for deviations from simple power-laws due to energy density effects or frequency dependence.

The gamma-ray emission is influenced by various factors such as the photon index, which ranges from 1.84 to 2.86 in non-blazar AGNs. The luminosity of these objects spans a wide range in the plane, with FRI radio galaxies typically having harder photon indices than SSRQs/NLSY1s.

Some sources exhibit short-timescale flux variability accompanied by spectral hardening or flares, indicating that their gamma-ray spectra are dynamic and complex. Long-timescale flux variability is also observed in several other sources, including 3C 111, Cen A core, 3C 207, 3C 275.1, 3C 380, 4C+39.23B, PKS 1502+036 and PKS 2004-447."}

title: In-flight measurement of Planck telescope emissivity
input: The Planck satellite in orbit mission ended in October 2013. Between the end of Low Frequency Instrument (LFI) routine mission operations and the satellite decommissioning, a dedicated test was also performed to measure the Planck telescope emissivity. The scope of the test was twofold: (i) to provide, for the first time in flight, a direct measure of the telescope emissivity; and (ii) to evaluate the possible degradation of the emissivity by comparing data taken in flight at the end of mission with those taken during the ground telescope characterization. The emissivity was determined by heating the Planck telescope and disentangling the system temperature excess measured by the LFI radiometers. Results show End of Life (EOL) performance in good agreement with the results from the ground optical tests and from in-flight indirect estimations measured during the Commissioning and Performance Verification (CPV) phase. Methods and results are presented and discussed.

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09421v1","explanation": "The Planck satellite's orbit around Earth is a region where thermal radiation plays a crucial role in understanding the interactions between celestial objects and their surroundings. \\n\\nThe term 'emissivity' refers to an object's ability to emit radiation relative to its surroundings, often expressed as a ratio or percentage. In this context, it is crucial for understanding how the telescope interacts with its environment through thermal radiation. The process involves heating the Planck telescope and measuring the system temperature excess using LFI radiometers. \\n\\nThe Low Frequency Instrument (LFI) had completed its routine tasks by then, allowing a dedicated test to be conducted on the Planck telescope before it was decommissioned. This test aimed at obtaining a direct measurement of the telescope's emissivity in flight and assessing any potential degradation of this property. The results indicate that the End-of-Life (EOL) performance aligns well with data from ground-based optical tests, suggesting good agreement between these measurements."}

title: Effective temperatures of red giants in the APOKASC catalogue and the mixing length calibration in stellar models
input: Red giants in the updated APOGEE-Kepler catalogue, with estimates of mass, chemical composition, surface gravity and effective temperature, have recently challenged stellar models computed under the standard assumption of solar calibrated mixing length. In this work, we critically reanalyse this sample of red giants, adopting our own stellar model calculations. Contrary to previous results, we find that the disagreement between the effective temperature scale of red giants and models with solar calibrated mixing length disappears when considering our models and the APOGEE-Kepler stars with scaled solar metal distribution. However, a discrepancy shows up when alpha-enhanced stars are included in the sample. We have found that assuming mass, chemical composition and effective temperature scale of the APOGEE-Kepler catalogue, stellar models generally underpredict the change of temperature of red giants caused by alpha-element enhancements at fixed [Fe/H]. A second important conclusion is that the choice of the outer boundary conditions employed in model calculations is critical. Effective temperature differences (metallicity dependent) between models with solar calibrated mixing length and observations appear for some choices of the boundary conditions, but this is not a general result

output.last_response: {"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09441v1","explanation":"Red giants are massive stars in a late stage of evolution, characterized by their mass and chemical composition. The APOGEE-Kepler catalogue provides estimates for these properties, which are crucial for understanding stellar behavior. Key terms such as mixing length require clarification: Mixing length refers to the distance that energy generated in a star's core can travel before being released at its surface; it is typically calibrated using solar values. \\n\\nStellar models rely on accurate estimates of mass and chemical composition to predict red giant behavior, but their accuracy depends on various factors including metal distribution. Metal distribution pertains to the abundance of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium, which affects a star's temperature and luminosity. The choice of outer boundary conditions employed in model calculations is critical for obtaining reliable results. \\n\\nStellar models generally underpredict the change in temperature caused by alpha-element enhancements at fixed [Fe/H]. This effect becomes more pronounced when including alpha-enhanced stars in the sample, leading to a discrepancy between predicted and observed effective temperatures. However, this disagreement disappears when considering our models and the APOGEE-Kepler stars with scaled solar metal distribution. \\n\\nThe choice of outer boundary conditions is critical because it affects the accuracy of stellar models in predicting red giant behavior. Effective temperature differences (metallicity dependent) between models with solar calibrated mixing length and observations appear for some choices of these boundary conditions, but this discrepancy is not a general result."}

title: Radiatively driven relativistic jets in Schwarzschild space-time
input: We carry out a general relativistic study of radiatively driven, conical fluid jets around non-rotating black holes and investigate the effects and significance of radiative acceleration, as well as radiation drag. We apply relativistic equations of motion in curved space-time around a Schwarzschild black hole for axis-symmetric 1-D jet in steady state, plying through the radiation field of the accretion disc. Radiative moments are computed using information of curved space-time. Slopes of physical variables at the sonic points are found using L Hôpital's rule and employed Runge-Kutta's order method to solve equations of motion. The analysis is carried out, using the relativistic equation of state of the jet fluid. The terminal speed of the jet depends on how much thermal energy is converted into jet momentum and how much radiation momentum is deposited on to the jet. Many classes of jet solutions with single sonic points, multiple sonic points as well as, those having radiation driven internal shocks are obtained. Variation of all flow variables along the jet-axis has been studied. Highly energetic electron-proton jets can be accelerated by intense radiation to terminal Lorentz factors . Moderate terminal speed is obtained for moderately luminous discs. Lepton dominated jets may achieve . Thermal driving of the jet itself and radiation driving by accretion disc photons produce a wide-ranging jet solutions staring from moderately strong jets to the relativistic ones. Interplay of intensity and nature of radiation field and the energetics of the jet result in such a variety in jet solutions. We show that radiation field is able to induce steady shocks in jets, one of the criteria to explain high energy power law emission observed in spectra of some of the astrophysical objects.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09489v1","explanation": "Black holes reside in regions of space where gravity is so strong that not even light can escape, warping the fabric of spacetime around them.

In this context, curved space-time refers to the distortion caused by massive objects like black holes, affecting nearby matter's motion. A Schwarzschild black hole has a well-defined curvature to both space and time.

Sonic points are critical in fluid dynamics, where the speed of a jet equals its sound speed, while Lorentz factors describe energy transfer from thermal to kinetic form. These concepts help understand radiatively driven jets around black holes.

Radiation interacts with matter in curved spacetime, inducing steady shocks that lead to high-energy power-law emission observed in some astrophysical objects. The terminal jet speed depends on the conversion of thermal energy into momentum and radiation deposition onto it."}

title: Production of sunspots and their effects on the corona and solar wind: Insights from a new 3D flux-transport dynamo model
input: We present a three-dimensional numerical model for the generation and evolution of the magnetic field in the solar convection zone, in which sunspots are produced and contribute to the cyclic reversal of the large-scale magnetic field. We then assess the impact of this dynamo-generated field on the structure of the solar corona and solar wind. This model solves the induction equation in which the velocity field is prescribed. This velocity field is a combination of a solar-like differential rotation and meridional circulation. We develop an algorithm that enables the magnetic flux produced in the interior to be buoyantly transported towards the surface to produce bipolar spots. We find that those tilted bipolar magnetic regions contain a sufficient amount of flux to periodically reverse the polar magnetic field and sustain dynamo action. We then track the evolution of these magnetic features at the surface during a few consecutive magnetic cycles and analyze their effects on the topology of the corona and on properties of the solar wind (distribution of streamers and coronal holes, and of slow and fast wind streams) in connection with current observations of the Sun.

output.last_response:
{"id":"http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.09625v1","explanation":"The solar convection zone is a region where magnetic fields are generated and evolve through the interaction of fluid motions and electromagnetic forces, driven by differential rotation and meridional circulation.

Differential rotation refers to the variation in rotational velocity with latitude, resulting in faster rotation at the equator than at higher latitudes. Meridional circulation describes the flow of material from the equator towards the poles. The dynamo-generated magnetic field plays a crucial role in shaping the solar corona's structure.

The interaction between fluid motions and electromagnetic forces generates magnetic fields that are then transported buoyantly towards the surface, producing bipolar spots with sufficient magnetic flux to periodically reverse the polar magnetic field and sustain dynamo action. This process affects the topology of the corona and properties of the solar wind.

Tilted bipolar magnetic regions contain a sufficient amount of flux to periodically reverse the polar magnetic field and sustain dynamo action, which has significant implications for understanding the structure of the solar corona and solar wind in relation to current observations."}
